In the mornings the Saône moved like a long sigh between stone and sky, and the fog made the city seem disposed to forgetfulness, its towers and red roofs dissolving into a gray breath that lifted and fell. Élise liked to walk from her apartment in Vaise toward the collège long before the children came pouring in, and she liked especially the cracked stretch of pavement beside the butcher that smelled faintly of fennel and rust. The air at that hour was damp enough to gather into her hair, a halo of soft frizz that her mothers would once have tut-tutted about. Her mother was dead now, but Élise still heard her sometimes—This is not how a teacher presents herself—like an old radio left playing somewhere behind there in childhood.

She tugged her scarf tighter and remembered that she had promised Camille she would look over the new poem, even though the girl would not need it; there was something in Camille that had begun to do its own work, a steady learning like a quiet motor. They were like that at thirteen, sometimes, full of buds that would not open for two or three years and then suddenly, one spring morning, a person. In the staff room, Renaud had already burned the coffee and was pretending, with a kind of brittle enthusiasm, that it had been on purpose to keep them awake.

“You’re too early,” he said when she came in. “It’s unhealthy.”

“We can split the unhealthiness then,” she said, hanging her coat on the back of a chair and pulling from her bag a plastic container of tiny tangerines, pocked and sweet. “I brought clementines.”

“I brought the smell of burnt.”

“Ah, a feast,” she said.

There were chalk dust crumbs on the table and somebody’s forgotten glove. The radiator clicked. It was the first Tuesday after the vacation and everyone had that look, a faint pallor that in six weeks would become fury. Renaud passed her a cup and she took a breath and drank. It was as awful as promised, but it made her heart flicker.

She taught them Prévert, that morning, and she had them read the lines out loud with their neat mouths because poetry should move through the body, because she had learned to love rhythm before she learned to love meaning. That was not a thing one could tell children without sounding like you were selling them a scented candle. She told them anyway. “Say it like you are not afraid of your own voice,” she said, and Camille raised her head and read, and the boy in the front row whose name always escaped her snapped his gum and tried to hide it in his sleeve, and outside, a truck scratched its way along the street and then was gone.

It was after lunch, after she had eaten a hard-boiled egg and a heel of bread at her desk, that the message arrived. It came by way of her phone lying among the corrected papers like a lost fish. It came like this: a number she did not recognize, then a voice, caught a moment by the school’s poor reception, and then a name. “Madame Martin? It’s Giraud. From Les Étoiles de la Cité.” She had to say pardon twice, and carried the phone into the hall where the tiles helped the signal find its courage.

“Yes?” she said, and her voice felt too thin.

“You entered the regionals last month with—” the woman paused, a rustle of paper, “—with a partner, Monsieur Costa? Rafaël Costa? I wanted to inform you that due to a disqualification, you are now qualified for the final round. It will be in Paris, the twelfth, at the Carré. We’d be delighted to have you. We sent an email yesterday but perhaps it went astray.”

It had gone astray. All her emails went astray because she did not care for them. She considered them like flies at a picnic, a necessary toleration. She made a sound. It was not quite language.

“Madame Martin?”

“Yes,” she said again. She had to sit down on the bench under the grim class photos where dozens of children had tried to make their faces into acceptable offerings to the future. “Yes. That is—merci.” She could hear her breath. She thought of Rafaël’s shoulders and the way his jaw clenched when he laughed. She thought of the tiny trophy they had not won the last time, how she had brushed the dust from its base with a fingertip while they waited for their number to be called. “It will be—next week?”

“The twelfth.”

“And the train—" She stopped herself. “No. Thank you. Yes. We will be there.”

“Please confirm by email,” said Madame Giraud. “There’s a small fee to secure the slot, but nothing significant, and you can pay upon arrival. We are, truly, quite delighted. You were radiant. Your boléro—” A tut of pleasure down the line. “If you’ll forgive my frankness, it made me cry.”

The line went dead and Élise sat there with the phone in both hands and stared at her reflection in it. She looked gray; she always looked gray in the school, as if the walls rubbed their chalk onto her. The twelfth. In Paris. She breathed the words into the hollow of her scarf. A laugh rose in her throat and she smothered it. She could not bear for laughter to escape into a place like this, where it would be eaten by days.

“Everything all right?” said Renaud, who had come to the door with a stack of worksheets and that look of a man carrying a birthday cake that he himself did not want.

“Everything is very well,” she said. “Better than well.”

“Is that allowed?”

She rose, and touched his sleeve impulsively. “I’ll tell you later. Imagine, we are quartz. We are shining.”

He looked at his worksheets as if they might hold an answer. “You are peculiar, Martin. But it’s good to see you be—what is that word? Éclairée.”

She spent the rest of the afternoon like a woman who had put down something heavy and was trying not to remember it. In 5B, when a boy called Yannis made a joke about Molière that turned his mouth into a little blade, she laughed and took the joke and twisted it into a lesson about farce, and the boy flushed in triumph. On the stairs a parent stopped her to ask about extra practice for exams, and she said yes to everything, and she understood nothing of what she was promising but felt she would pay it all later out of a deep reservoir of grace. The children went home into a rain that had begun precisely at four; the courtyard filled with umbrellas and yelling, and then reduced itself to a few late walkers and the sound of a ball failing to be caught.

She sent a message to Rafaël. It said only: Can we talk? 7 at the studio? It added, in the end, because she could not help herself: Paris.

His reply came with unreasonable slowness. He worked long hours wherever it was he worked, down in some belly of a building where wires were snakes and insulation was snow. He often had blisters. He often had a look that made her want to press her fingertips to his wrists. It arrived just as she reached her apartment: Affirmative, star. 7. And a small blue star. He had a way with emojis that made them seem like pebbles he had picked up from a beach.

In her apartment the heat was a stubborn old dog that only came when it was called five, six times. She turned it on and waited. The wall by the door had a stain that looked like Corsica. She kicked off her shoes and put on the kettle and stood in the small kitchen where a single glass was drying on a towel and a bowl of lemons stubbornly refused to sweeten the air. She was not poor, not exactly, and yet she held her breath when she checked the bank app on her phone, the way a swimmer holds a breath before looking through green water for the bottom.

The numbers were what the numbers always were, a little obtuse. Enough to live. Not enough to play, not without counting. She had been telling herself this for so long it had become a lullaby. She closed the app. She drank her tea standing up. She looked at herself in the mirror that hung above the sink and saw that she was thirty-six, that is, almost forty, that is, not young and not the end of anything, that is, a person who might yet do a thing she cared about. She stuck her tongue out at herself and then laughed and went to find her dance bag.

She paused at the postcard pinned above her desk, the one of the Palais Garnier at night, and touched the edge of it with her nail. This was what she wanted: to slide into a dress that smelled of oranges and metal and to walk out onto a stage and discover that the floor had the same kind of spring as a kiss. She had started too late, as everyone told you you were not supposed to do, and she knew with an almost sweet clarity that she would never be a professional, never earn anything from this, and that because of that she had to return to it again and again, like a cat to a door it did not believe was closed.

She put on her coat and went back out, down the stair with its greased wooden banister, across to the street where the night had spread itself like ink. The studio was three tram stops away, down past the bakery that made a baguette with olives that tasted like holidays. Inside the studio the air was warm and sharp with human ambition. There were three couples in a corner working out the mechanics of a turn and a boy with earbuds doing acrobatics in the mirror. The long wall of glass reflected everyone twice, three times, into different versions of themselves.

“Star,” said Rafaël, from the bleachers. He wore an old sweater with holes and a grin that lived mostly in his mouth. He did not stand up, but opened his arms and she went into them, because that was their arrangement, an arrangement that had its rules. They were more than friends and less than lovers and exactly partners. They held on longer than was necessary and then let go.

“Say it,” he said. “Say it out loud, so we know if it’s real.”

“We’re in the final round,” she said. “Paris. The twelfth. The Carré.”

He let out a shout that made heads turn. Then he kissed the air near her cheek and did a sort of foolish dance that looked like a dance of a man mocked by happiness and grateful for it. “I told you,” he said. “I told you they weren’t blind.”

“You told me we were good enough to frighten small dogs.”

“Perhaps I was translating. There is only so much my French can do.”

His French was fine; he had been here since he was nine. She loved to mock him for his agreeable vowels, the way a Portuguese made everything sound a little tender. He grabbed her bag and carried it as if it weighed nothing. “The twelfth,” he said, and the word seemed to take up space in his mouth. “We will kill them.”

She held his arm. The word kill made her think of knives and judges and the way her heart had stopped in the regionals just before their music began. “We will not die,” she said. “We will dance.”

For an hour they worked, not because it mattered anymore, but because it always mattered. They whooped, they bickered, they counted: five, six, seven, eight. Her feet were fine; it was her head that failed. Sometimes she stood there, looking, and could not move forward into the next thing. He knew that place in her. He stood off the line of her body until she could feel him like a town behind her shoulder, and then she moved. They spoke little. The music did the part that words always do wrong.

When they paused, he looked at her. “Do you have—” he had an expression he wore when he was about to say something she would not like, “—you have the train covered?”

“Of course,” she said, quickly.

“Because I can advance you,” he said, looking away at the mirror. “It’s not a problem. They are paying me early for the job near Oullins. The one with the leak.”

She wiped sweat from her forehead with the collar of her shirt. She had a blue bruise inside her right thigh where their knees had kissed too hard in a dip. She thought of her bank app like a small, square window that opened onto a cliff. “I am not an orphan,” she said. She smiled. The joke was a bit poor. “I’m fine.”

“Okay,” he said. He did not believe her. He would bring it up again, because he loved her in the way one loves a dance partner or a lost cousin; he would pretend not to, because he loved her in the second way too, perhaps, and the pretending was tenderer than anything more violent. “We have to find a dress.”

She had one, of course, but it had lost some of its power with the season. It had been red once, and now it was that color of a tomato that has had its finest days. She pictured herself in the bright square of the Paris stage, a smudge. She swallowed. “I’ll manage.”

“You always manage,” he said, and he meant it as praise, but she heard the other thing in it, the piety of surviving.

They changed the music and went again. He put his hand at the small of her back and they slipped like two pieces of a machine into the turn that had broken them in the regional. This time the floor would not accept her heel; it slid, and she stumbled and caught herself on his shoulder with a little sound that was not exactly pain and not exactly fear. He laughed once, under his breath. “Again,” he said.

Later, when the studio had emptied and the boy with the earbuds had gone to wherever boys with earbuds go, they sat on the bleachers and drank from a bottle of water and let their bodies think things over. The window was a plain square of night.

“Do you ever think of stopping?” he asked suddenly, as if the question had been waiting for the right breath to sit on. “If we win—if we lose—do you ever think of just not having the need any more?”

She watched the mirror’s empty face. She thought of her mother standing in the doorway of the kitchen with one hand pressed into the small of her back and a beautiful hatred of illness on her mouth. “Sometimes I think of stopping,” she said. “Sometimes I think I can’t stop. And sometimes I imagine doing just one thing well and then forgetting it forever. Like being nineteen and kissing someone who will not matter and doing it so completely that you have nothing left, so you cannot ever ask for that from anyone again.”

He laughed softly. “It is good we are not nineteen.”

“Speak for yourself.”

On the tram home the world looked like photographs taken through the bottom of a lake. Her hands smelled of that studio smell, a mix of pine cleaner and breath. She put her head back and closed her eyes and let the word Paris roll through her. She could see the train in her mind, the stupid mouth of it opening, the stupid red seats, the track repeating itself under them, this ordinary miracle of locomotion. She remembered the competition’s lights, how they flicker before they settle, that way the blown dust at the top of an auditorium catches the light so that one imagines falling gold. She imagined applause, but it was always the hush she wanted—the way sound gets thicker when a room waits.

Her phone buzzed. It was Camille. The message was shy. Madame, if you have time tomorrow, will you look at the poem? I added a part. My mother says it is too much but what can you do.

She wrote back: Yes. Bring your mother’s too-much part. I like too much.

Then, for no good reason, she counted her wallet’s contents on her knees—this childish thing, the way one counts pebbles—twenty, ten, ten, a single two-euro, some coins that had no right to exist. She put them back and felt suddenly as if she were wearing a coat that had been made for someone else. She almost messaged Rafaël. She did not.

At home she made a soup out of the carrots and a sad onion and ate it standing up again, with a little crude pepper so she could pretend it was fierce. She found the email from Les Étoiles, sitting in the junk folder among offers to enlarge things she did not have. It was as Madame Giraud had said. There was a small fee and a form that asked for sizes and for a song and for an emergency contact. She put down no one for that last, and then she did put someone: Jules, her brother, whom she had not spoken to in three months and who had sent her a text that said simply, I can’t continue to watch you do this to yourself. He was a kind man in a way that made him impossible. She put his number and hoped nothing would happen that required kindness.

It was when she reached the section about travel and accommodations that she paused too long. She did not have to book a hotel—they offered a cheap one—but she would need to secure her ticket to Paris. There were trains every hour, almost, and they were not expensive, not in the way that a dress was expensive or the cost of a mother’s medicine was expensive. And yet she felt as if the numbers might do that thing numbers sometimes did: cease to belong to her.

She closed the computer and went to fill the bath. The apartment’s pipes were old enough to remember better times. The water came a little brown at first and then it cleared, as if it had made up its mind. She undressed with a briskness she used for many things. She looked down at her stomach as she stepped in and thought, unkindly, almost automatically, of the girls at the studio with their knees like fresh breadsticks, and then she pushed the thought away and sank until the water came up to her ears, where everything sounds faithful.

She dreamed that night, as she often did after dancing, and the dream was of a hall with floors that refused every foot but hers. She was alone in the center and the chairs were filled with women with her mother’s hair who watched her with faces that could have been either love or contempt. She woke before the applause, with tears that seemed to have been put there by someone else.

The next day began with a clatter—the neighbor’s young man dropping his bicycle on the landing and swearing in a whisper—and came back to its normal rhythm, as days do. At school the photocopier refused one of her requests, then accepted another with a grudge. The teacher who taught maths wore a tie he had definitely bought to be a joke that had matured into a tragedy. After third period, the headmaster called a short meeting to say that there would be cuts to the field trips this year and that any excursions must be justified with something more than “enrichment.” There was a murmur that was not exactly agreement and not exactly rage; the teachers swam in it like fish in a small bowl.

She told Renaud at break. The coffee was less burnt but somehow more offensive.

“I’m in the final,” she said, trying to say it as if it were a thing that could be spoken in a staff room. “Paris. We go next week.”

“You’re—?” For a moment he stood very straight, like someone a conductor has asked to make a noise. “Brava.” He said it the Italian way because last year he had fallen in love with an opera singer and entirely used up the word bravo. “What does that entail?”

“We dance. People watch. There is a trophy with small gladiators on it. Very serious business.”

He lifted his cup in a toast. “Bring a gladiator to the staff room.”

“It will go very well with the burnt coffee.”

In the afternoon Camille came with the poem and her flushed cheeks. She sat at the edge of the desk with a kind of hunger. Élise read the poem quickly first, then again slowly. It was not bad. It had one perfect line—my father walks around the house like a jacket that has forgotten the body—and a great many lines that were in love with their own handwriting. They talked about killing darlings without naming it that. They talked about leaving air in the poem for someone else to come in and sit down. Camille nodded like this had been what she’d been trying to do all week and now could not wait to do properly. “You are too much,” she said as she gathered her paper. “But I think I like too much.”

“Your mother will have to live,” said Élise.

After school she caught the tram two stops too far, distracted by an old man asleep with his mouth open, by a poster that said something to her and then said it again differently. She walked back along the river, which today was green like an inexplicable cup, and through the market where men called apple names to her and women stacked tomatoes like rubies. She wanted everything. She bought two pears and an orange as if they were ideas. At home she weighed the bank app like a word on her tongue that she did not want to pronounce. She waited. There was no sudden influx of money from a benevolent aunt. There was the same ordinary handful of days between now and pay day and the same ledger of bills that had been waiting for her since she became her own person.

She made a list. It said: rent. electricity. telephone. metro. food. then, in small letters, dance. She stuck it on the fridge and then laughed because of course it had nothing to do with a list. She would go to Paris even if she had to walk. She would go to Paris even if she had to sit in the aisle and pretend she was a bag.

Then she thought of asking Jules. She thought of calling and hearing his voice, the one he had learned to make like a spoon—warm, offering. She thought of refusing the spoon because it would mean something she would hate. She put the phone back down without picking it up.

At the studio that evening, they worked with a quiet fervor that people who do not know dance might call obsession and people who do know dance might call habitation. She had eaten the orange beforehand and her tongue was sweet. They chose their music. Something Cuban that had a brass that rose like a hand. They argued about the last thirty seconds.

“It should be risk,” said Rafaël, touching his chest where the music entered. “If it is not risk, it is not art. It is accountancy.”

“I like accountancy,” she said, smiling, but she did not like it; she liked risk and hated losing.

He said, “We are not here to be careful.”

They arranged the last thirty seconds to break them and then brought it back a little so they might live. It was not perfect. Nothing was. “I will have to get a dress,” she said, again, like a woman who says I will have to get a second job, like a woman who says I will have to learn to forgive.

“I can keep the boys at the site late,” said Rafaël. “Make them work two more days if necessary. Then I will give you the money and you will be obliged to accept, because you have already accepted my hand and my lead and therefore you accept everything.”

“You talk like a man whose mother loved him too well,” she said, and he laughed at that, a catch in the laugh that was not exactly pain.

After, in the cool corridor, an old woman with a bun and a fuchsia backpack stopped Élise with a hand on her elbow. “Mademoiselle?” she said, as if the word had failed and fallen back to the ground of another era. “I saw you. You are—please forgive me—beautiful when you dance. The rest of the time you are ordinary, like the rest of us. But there—” she placed her hand very delicately at Élise’s sternum, “—there you are like a bell.”

Elise smiled. “Merci.”

“Go to Paris,” said the woman, as if she knew everything about it. “Do not let anyone stop you.”

At home, a message waited from her landlord that said simply: Reminder. The rent must be paid by the tenth. It had a smiley face, which felt like a threat. She sat down on the couch that had belonged to her mother and stared at the place where a thread had withstood a thousand sit-downs. She could hear the upstairs couple arguing again, but softly, the way people argue after they have made a vow not to.

She took the envelope out from under the shelf where she kept envelopes. It contained eighty euros in cash, a number she had been carefully not counting since last month. She put it on the table and laid the coins from her wallet beside it. It was not nothing. It was not enough. She counted them anyway, piling them like stones.

She thought, with a sudden terrible sweetness, about stealing the money. Not from a person, never from a person; she could not bear taking the softness out of someone else’s day. But from a system that would not notice. She thought of the school’s petty cash box, which you had to sign for, and the way it had not been counted lately because Madame Aujoulat’s father had been ill. She felt the thought and then she threw it from her, a small bird. It went to the window and tapped there and then went away.

She wrote a message to Jules and then did not send it. It said: This is childish. It said: You are right: I am doing this to myself. It said: If I do not do this, I do not know what I am for.

She went to bed. She dreamed again—the hall now had a ceiling of glass and rain fell on it like beads on a drum—she went through the turn that had always been a small cruelty and came out of it as if she had not been hurt in any of this. When she woke, she had the taste of pears in her mouth and could not say why.

On Thursday she took her class to the library and watched them be briefly quiet, which was a miracle she did not even require faith for, because the library had done its work for longer than any of them had been alive. She caught a glimpse, in the glass of a bookcase, of a woman who was not herself, or rather was herself if she had been the person she had thought she would be at twenty. It made her laugh at nothing and made her sad in that way that is not tragedy but is its little cousin.

At lunch she finally called Giraud to confirm, and the woman’s voice was brisk with the delight of someone whose job was to put ribbons around people’s desire. “We look forward to seeing you,” she said. “Truly. Bring your music on a USB stick. Bring your papers. Bring your luck.”

She went then to the ticket site and found the trains. She chose a time that would place them in the capital three hours before they needed to be anywhere and ticked a box for a seat by a window as if this would change the course of her life. When she reached the place where you put your card numbers in, she felt her heart step into some older rhythm. It was like being a child again, balancing on a wall and looking down at gravel. She typed them. The site thought. The site thought longer.

She had ninety-three euros left until the tenth. The tickets would be seventy-six each if they were not purchased with hope but with reality. She did not have one seventy-six. She had one ninety-three. She cancelled. She closed the computer. She went to the sink and washed a glass that was already clean.

She would borrow from Rafaël. It would be a joke between them that stung less because of their jokes. She would borrow and then pay him back with money earned from invigilation and two weeks of not buying pears. She could do it. The thought sat on her shoulder. It was not a good bird and not a bad bird; it was just a bird.

The day went on. She taught, she smiled at Renaud when he tried to sing a line from Prévert and came out with something like Édith Piaf being sad in a hallway. She went to the market and touched the lemons and did not buy them. She returned home and took the envelope out again and counted again and the numbers became tender in their inadequacy, like a man one knows will never love you, no matter how one speaks.

In the evening she went to the studio and found Rafaël not yet there. She stretched, gently, as she was supposed to do, and then less gently, as she always ended up doing, because patience was not the same as virtue. A young couple practiced something furious, all elbows, and the radio tried to sell them a milk. She looked down at her shoes, these faithful leather things, and thought of Paris like a place in a book she had loved at thirteen and not had the money to buy.

When Rafaël arrived, he smelled of dust and rain and he kissed her cheek quickly, twice, three times as if he had missed and needed to correct. “We will practice the last second until our feet beg us to stop,” he said. “But first—”

He pressed a small envelope into her hand. He had written her name on it in a schoolboy hand, the f choking the i. “Before you start to protest,” he said, raising his palms, “it is not charity. It is an investment. It is an investment in my own glory, because I have no chance without you, and that makes this transaction very pure. It is more pure than love. It’s geometry.”

She worked the flap of the envelope back and forth and then put it back in her bag unopened. “If it is geometry,” she said, “then you can calculate the angle of my gratitude.”

“Your gratitude is obtuse,” he said, grinning. “It takes up the whole circle. And it has sharp corners.”

She did not protest. She would protest later. They danced until the muscles behind her knees trembled like mice. When they finished, the studio’s cleaning woman was waiting, arms folded, to chase them out. In the street, the damp had a hunger. He walked her to the tram stop and then, impulsively, as the tram arrived, pressed his palm once to her cheek. “We will do it,” he said. “We will be a story they tell to their children who will not care.” He laughed. “It will make us furious.”

On the tram, she touched the place where his hand had been and thought of all the hands that had ever touched her and how they seemed now like a series of emulsions, layers, like the way garlic comes in its small papers. She took out the envelope and opened it and counted quickly: fifty, a hundred, two, two-twenty. It was too much and then not enough and then absolutely right. She felt that stew of shame and relief that sits inside acts of kindness. She sighed. She wanted to tell someone and there was no one to tell who would not make of it a diagnosis.

At home she booked the tickets. The site hummed itself into action and then spat them into her email like small birds she would have to keep warm. She stood there a long time, watching the spinner, and then felt a happiness so ridiculous, so unshaped, that she had to say something aloud to give it walls. “Paris,” she said, to the empty room. “Paris, Paris.”

That night she could not sleep. She lay there and watched the ceiling insist upon itself, that very particular French ceiling with its thin cracks like maps of lost territories. She tried to orchestrate her thoughts: train time, warm up schedule, food, water, sleep, the dress, a contingency plan for the moment her mind might refuse her, as it did sometimes because it was old habit to refuse itself what it wanted most. She imagined writing to Jules and saying I am in the final can you believe and the message coming back with his big-hands words. She turned over and smelled the winter coming in through the window.

In the morning, a sound like the end of distant construction woke her. She went to the kitchen, opened the fridge, thought about breakfast, decided to be a person who ate yogurt. She wrote an email to Camille about the poem and included an attachment of something by Szymborska that she loved like a secret. She put on the newish sweater she had bought in a moment of optimism in September, and a necklace she did not wear often, because she wanted the day to be heavy around her neck in a good way.

In the stairwell, the neighbor’s boy was sitting on the step with his bike upside down, working the chain with black fingers. “Ça va?” she said, because that is what you say.

“Ça tient,” he said without looking up, which is the truth of many things.

On the way to school she passed the big poster of the dance finals that someone had pasted to the wall near the tram. She wasn’t on the poster, of course; it had a woman with a mouth like a promise and a man with arms that looked like good architecture. She stopped and looked, and then she looked away and then she looked back again, like a child not allowed to stare at something delicious. She wrote to Rafaël: We must be ridiculous; they will throw flowers and we will break our ankles trying to pick them up. He wrote back a picture of a gladiator.

At school she was called into the headmaster’s office. He was a neat man who wore his small authority like a jacket he was afraid of dirtying. “Madame Martin,” he said, “I have a favor to ask. The exams require two invigilators this Saturday. We have no one.”

She thought of the studio, of practicing with the panic of a person who had decided to believe in something. She thought too of the envelope with its bilingual coins. “Of course,” she said. “What time?”

“Nine until noon,” he said. “I knew I could rely on you. You are dependable.”

She didn’t know whether to be pleased or insulted. Dependable is not a word that gets invited to the finals of anything. She said yes again to the universe in general, and then went back to class and drew a diagram of a sentence on the board and made jokes about the way adjectives are like people who arrive late to parties and discover that everything they have to say has already been said.

In the quiet between classes, the world felt far away. She thought again of the year her mother had been ill and how thick the air had been in that apartment, sweet with syrups and despair, and how the bodies of the nurses had moved through it like ships. She thought of how she had begun then to go to the free salsa in the park, to learn not the dance exactly but the permission to stand in a place and take up space. It was a permission she had never had in the house, where her mother had been the size of everything. It was not a story she ever told now, because people got very close to your face when you told them something like that, and she was not interested in that closeness.

She stood at the window and watched a boy kiss a girl on the mouth behind the rubbish bins, and she smiled, and then she thought of the little turtle she and Jules had had when they were children, the way it had put its head out of the shell like a question mark, the way it had disappeared one day and never been found. She wrote Jules: I miss you. She did not send it. She put her phone away like a candy she had decided to save for later and then intended to hide from herself.

As the week turned, she felt the city begin to breathe faster. It was probably only her. The deadline for the rent crept its fingers through the days. She checked her account again, and used the precise part of her mind to divide the money for bread from the money for cow’s milk. She imagined the train with its light like a clean forehead, and the station air, and the way Paris always smelled a little like gasoline and a little like old stone and something else, maybe frankness.

When Friday evening came she and Rafaël danced as if the floor itself were a person they wanted to seduce. They did not talk much. There is a point at which talk only frightens what must come. When she left the studio she kissed his cheek too and tasted salt and then the city came over her like a shawl. The tram was late. Two girls sang softly that song that everyone was singing and made it sound less like a funeral. The night was full of little red things—tail lights, the last leaves, a scarf someone had dropped.

At home, the rent notice had come under the door, printed, like a calling card. She picked it up and placed it on the table, as if giving it a chair would civilize it. She took the envelope from her bag and put it alongside the notice. She took the little cash from the jar where she sometimes kept coffee coins. She made a neat stack. She did this as if she were a person in a film who knows that paper will change a life. She calculated the train tickets in her head and felt a small lurch at the bottom of the sum. She would be short. And if she paid the landlord first, she would not get to Paris. And if she paid the train, she would have to go to the landlord and make a shape with her mouth that said, Je vous promets.

She sat very still. Water in the radiators made a sound like wood remembering fire. The lights of a car moved along the ceiling.

She thought, for a moment that stretched too long, of not going. Of stepping back from the little precipice she had brought herself to and deciding that the sensible thing, the prudent thing, the grown-up thing, would be to be prudent and grown. That she could be the teacher who never left the city, the woman who lit a candle for herself and read in bed until she was eighty. She thought it and then she put it down, and the putting down was like lifting a piano with two fingers.

She took her shoes off and set them side by side. She put the notice face down; the white rectangle of it became just paper again. She poured herself a glass of water and drank half of it and put it down and then she stood, because standing sometimes changes the nature of a decision. She picked up her phone and wrote to Rafaël: Tomorrow after invigilation, we will practice until no. She did not finish the sentence. He replied with a fist and a star.

She went to bed smiling at nothing. The radiator clucked. In the space just before sleep, she saw the inside of the train again, and heard the voice that would announce their arrival, the way those voices pretend to be human and then give up.

And below the dream, below the moving and the making of lists and the small arithmetic of a life, there was, as always, an image that had come to her when she was a girl: a stage, a light that found her and made her edges crisp, a sound that connected the bones of her feet to the ancient, unnecessary, astonishing drum in her chest. It was foolish. It was not. It had accompanied her through worse than poverty, through grief that had taught her the name of every hour of the night. It was the door she tapped at, at midnight, and sometimes it opened and sometimes it did not, but always, always, she could see the light under it, and that was enough to keep her there, singing a little nonsense tune until someone turned the knob.Saturday placed its heavy hand on the building early, so that the stairwell already smelled of damp wool and pencil shavings when Élise left for the collège. The invigilation box sat squat on the desk in the office with its packet of extra pens and its roll of numbered labels that made every child temporarily a receipt. She signed for the key and took a breath that tasted of yesterday’s photocopies, then walked to the assigned room with the deliberate pace of someone escorting themselves. The windows there had the institutional view she always loved—sky, a portion of a plane tree, the top of a bus stop where someone had written a declaration of love that used up all its vowels.

They came in holding their fear the way one holds a plate of soup: two hands, high, careful. She greeted them, named the rules, repeated them, set the papers face down like towels, and then they began. Silence arrived in its particular shoes. It was not the silence of churches, nor the silence of deep winter, but that civic pause people enter when they agree, without discussing it, that they will behave as if they, together, can be trustworthy. There was the coughed apology, the scrape of a chair foot across linoleum, the steady saw of the hallway’s distant cleaning machine. For a while, she forgot she wanted anything besides this—a room of people trying with their whole bodies to put a thought into a small square. The hush thickened so pleasantly that she had to stop herself from smiling, in case a child mistook it for cruelty or a trap.

Halfway through, the boy with the deliciously destructive jokes, Yannis, lifted his head, met her eyes with a sort of adolescent honesty, and then let his gaze slide to the left. The girl beside him stiffened in that way the body does when it knows it is about to be offered a sin. Élise raised her eyebrows and walked as if to the window, pausing so near their desk that they could smell her tea breath. She did not speak. She did not have to. The long corridor of years ahead of them would be full of rooms like this and chances to become either the person who helps or the person who pretends not to see. The boy looked down, the girl exhaled, the small moral city within the school continued to stand.

When it was over, there was a sound like discarded armor as the children put down their pens. They filed out blinking, temporarily lighter, like people leaving a cinema. She collected the papers, shuffled them, sealed them with an official sticker that was only glue and yet, apparently, a guarantee that the world would keep its promises. In the staff room, Renaud applauded lazily with his fingers against his own palm and offered her the last brioche from a bag that had failed to keep it tender. They ate in solidarity with themselves. “You will go this afternoon and make the floor ask for mercy,” he said, and she liked him for understanding that this was a thing one could want.

She changed at the studio only partially, keeping her school skirt and exchanging her blouse for a tank, and for a moment the half-costume felt like the perfect outfit for her life—one foot in one world and the other insisting on rhythm. Rafaël arrived late, hair wet with the rain he had refused to avoid, and his apology was a grin with its hat in its hand. They worked without talking about it, in the way people do who have spent a very long time learning the grammar of each other’s hips. The last thirty seconds, which had been a negotiation with risk, turned into an argument with gravity. Three times they took the turn that held in it the possibility of farce or flight, and three times she felt her heel kiss the floor exactly once like a polite guest. He did not let go of her hand even when they were safe. “You see,” he said, later, warm breath on her temple, “you see, star, the body learns even when the mind is trying to pay the rent.”

When they stopped, the clocks everywhere seemed to discover that they had been neglected and began to announce themselves. She sat on the bleachers and found that her skirt had acquired a chalk smear that looked like the ghost of a palm. The envelope in her bag felt like a second heart. If she closed her eyes, she could see the sectioned red of the train seats and the smear of countryside that would serve as a thinking place. “We need a dress,” Rafaël said, as if the sentence might conjure one.

“I have been imagining the dress like a country,” she said. “I plan to move there and become a minor official.”

“You will be the minister of making people gasp,” he said, making a little courtly bow with his stupid holey sweater, and she wanted to kiss the crown of his head the way one kisses a child before sending him somewhere dangerous.

On Sunday, the city put on its underclothes and went out anyway. The market along the quai was flapped into shape by wind; the women who sold cheese held knives whose reflections looked like birds. She had made a plan that seemed to her like a good lie—she would find something secondhand that felt like a secret agreeing to be visible. The first shop smelled of starch and old quarrels. A bell announced her and a woman without eyebrows gave her a glance that felt like a sting test. There were dresses in every register of the past: taffeta sighs, beaded sentences, the optimisms of decades she had not been alive for. She touched them the way one touches a dream, with the tips of her fingers. None of them were right, not because they were ugly—they were all beautiful, even the ridiculous ones—but because they were stories that would not be hers to tell.

In a smaller shop on the side street where the pavement buckled over the roots of an arrogant plane tree, she found a dress that had once been worn by a woman who believed in telephones that connected quickly. It was a dark green that sometimes thought it was black, cut on the bias with the particular intelligence of someone who liked knees. Sequins were absent, which made her feel more honest. The price, penciled on a tag with a cheerful lie, was less awful than she had feared, but not nothing. “Try,” said the woman behind the counter, who was not the kind of woman with eyebrows but was the kind with wrists that had done work.

In the curtained space where all the mirrors disagreed with each other a little, she put it on. It slid over her like a kind argument. The strap on the left side had seen things and needed a sure needle. The hem would have to learn where her ankle was. But the dress did to her shoulders what she pretended not to know she wanted dresses to do. She stepped out and the woman put her head to one side, appraising with the practice of a person who has watched many strangers come out of many curtains. “If you were two centimeters taller,” she said, “I would call it destiny. As it is, we will call it work.”

“I can pay a deposit,” Élise said, and the sentence made a clean wound in the air. The woman nodded, as if the air had been bleeding all day, and named a number with the mercy in it already. Élise counted out bills and felt both humiliated and saved. They made arrangements like people make arrangements about children at the end of parties—when to return, where to meet, what to do if the weather changed its mind. She stepped back into her own clothes and felt as if she had removed not a dress but a version of herself that had reluctantly agreed to exist.

Back at the apartment, the rent notice lay where she had left it, patient, sure of itself in the way only paper seems allowed to be. The tenth would be Monday. She sat down to compose a message to the landlord that would sound the way she needed it to sound: apologetic but dignified, temporary in its request, explicit in its promise. She stared at the empty message and thought of Jules’s spoon-voice. She thought of the envelope in her bag and the cash she had kissed into train tickets and deposit. She called instead of writing, because she had learned that sometimes the sound of a human throat can do what text cannot.

“Madame Hanriot,” she said when the woman answered, and then apologised for calling on a Sunday because she was French and had been raised to respect leisure as if it were a religion. “It’s Martin. In 3C. I wanted to ask if I might pay on the twelfth. There has been a delay. I can bring it to you, first thing, before I go to work.”

There was a pause, full and businesslike. She could hear, behind the woman, a television that had not decided whether to be tragic or entertaining. “The twelfth is after the tenth,” said Madame Hanriot, as if mathematics might persuade her that kindness had no place here.

“I know,” said Élise, and let her voice show its naked hands. “It will not be a habit. It will be this once. If it were not—” and here she almost said if it were not the dance but bit the words back because it would only make her sound childish and, besides, not everyone believed in the ways one saved oneself—“if it were not this week, I would not ask.”

Another pause, then the sound of a woman taking off a pair of glasses and putting them back on. “The twelfth,” the landlord said at last. “But you will bring it. You will not slide it under my door at midnight. And you will not make me call you again.”

“I will bring it,” said Élise, who could have gone on saying it like a mantra, because sometimes saying yes is the only proof one can offer.

She hung up and stood completely still just long enough to feel the tears come and go without lodging. The relief made a kind of space in her that she immediately filled with dread of what she had promised. She opened the window a little and the city sent in a smell of wet leaves and motor oil that did more for her than any perfume.

On Monday the school returned to its riverbed. Children poured and pooled; grown-ups built small banks with their bodies. Camille came to her at break, poem in hand and a giddiness on her face like a secret she was willing to share. “I took the line about the jacket out,” she said breathlessly, “because I thought it was maybe a different poem. But then I made something new with it at home, and maybe it is two poems, and I felt a little like a thief and a little like God.”

“That is writing,” said Élise, who wanted to say everything else as well, wanted to say I am proud of you and I would like to live in those little seconds where you discover yourself, but who knew not to pack a child’s pockets with adult sentences. “Bring both tomorrow. We will see which is which, and they will both be themselves.”

Renaud, later, leaned against her classroom door with a paper cup he had for once not burned and said, “I spoke to Anne this weekend,” with a studied lightness that meant this was a sentence with a heavy core. Anne was the opera singer who had taught him what it was to be both astonished and exhausted by a person. “She said she would come to Paris if she could get the Sunday train. She said to tell you that a stage is a ship and if you are not a little sick you are not far enough from shore.”

“Anne is a menace,” Élise said, and they both smiled because love and menace often share a wardrobe. “Does she have—” she began, and then did not want to say it. “Does she have, by any chance, opinions about dresses that have holes in their straps?”

Renaud’s look brightened with the relief of someone who has been waiting to be useful. “Opinions are her raw material,” he said, taking out his phone as if opinions could be ordered like bread. “She will have a sewing kit the size of a pharmacy. She will live for this.”

The days made their little beads and slid along the string. When the tenth passed like a truck that did not stop at her door, she felt temporarily lightheaded and then, sensibly, went and lay down on the couch for ten minutes to let her blood think. The dress was ready for its trial. The woman at the shop had made the strap suddenly certain and had taught the hem to respect her ankle. When Élise turned in the mirror, she saw someone who could pass for the kind of person who deserves a trumpet. She held very still and let the feeling pass through without resistance, the way she had learned to let grief pass through years ago, so that it would not settle stubbornly in an organ and declare itself king.

On Tuesday evening, the studio belonged to them. The boy with the earbuds had gone early to a job in a pizzeria; the furious couple had broken up in a way that involved chairs and apologies and then returned to the room pretending to have learned something. The air had that soft electrical smell that studios and power stations share. She warmed her ankles with devotion. He did the ridiculous jumps that made him feel like a boy again and made her feel that the ceiling was only a suggestion. They ran the piece in full, paused, altered the smallest gesture at the ninth second because sometimes it is the ninth second that saves you. When they stopped, a fine trembling had taken up residence in her hands. He looked at her and nodded as if to say yes, this is how we know we are alive.

Outside, the city offered an evening that had been cut slightly too short and mended with neon. They walked without meaning to, past the bakery with its olive bread, past the shop where she had not bought lemons, past a man who was singing a song to himself that had no words. “When we get there,” said Rafaël, “we will do our forgetting. We will forget the list, we will forget that there is a name for what we are doing, we will forget that other people have eyes.” He looked at her and had that look he sometimes had, the one that made her think of bridges, not because he wanted to cross, but because he understood the engineering. “We will not forget each other,” he added, almost as an afterthought, and the afterthought was truer than the sentence.

At home, there was a message from Jules. It had two parts. The first was a photograph of a turtle shell that had washed up on a beach he had been visiting with his children, the kind of thing the sea gives you like a joke. The second was a sentence that said, simply, I was not kind. The sentence had been written as if it had to be smuggled past guards. She held the phone and walked circles in the small apartment as if planning a parade. She wrote back, finally, I am in the final. There will be a trivial trophy. There will be music. I will be in Paris on Tuesday. She sent it without reading it again, because if she read it again she would begin to make it polite, and nothing has ever been saved by politeness.

That night, she dreamed of the studio clean and empty. The windows were open on every wall and the river had come in without bothering to use the door and was moving the benches around with the gentle entitlement of an old friend. She stepped into the water in her dress and it did not cling to her; it moved the way seaweed moves, on purpose and with a sense of humor. There were spectators on the bleachers, but their faces were not her mother’s. They were people she did not know, which felt like mercy. When she woke, she could still feel the slight resistance water gives to a calf, and it gave her a confidence she did not accept with her mind but accepted with her ankles.

The train day arrived at last with the ridiculous precision of a clock whose hands had been chastened. She woke before the alarm because happiness is a good alarm. She ate half a banana and a piece of toast with nothing on it, because stomachs at such times are conservative. She packed the USB stick with the music as if it were a vial of medicine. She put the dress into a bag that made no claim to its grandeur. Her apartment felt suddenly like a stage set for a life she would pick up again on Wednesday, plates standing in little cities on the drying rack, a book on the arm of the chair open to the place where a woman was about to say something foolish. She turned off the radiators as if she were saying goodbye to a pet.

At the station, the boards with their brittle clatter presented the city with its choices. People took themselves to be delivered. Rafaël arrived with a suitcase he had borrowed from a cousin, a square thing with stickers from places neither of them had been. He had shaved, which suited him and made her suspicious. “I did not sleep,” he confessed, and then immediately slept for ten minutes on the plastic seat while she watched their bags and the enormous minutes roll by.

On the platform, as the train made its long flirtation with stopping, Anne appeared like a person herself late from an aria. She wore a jacket the color of dangerous fruit and had, indeed, a sewing kit. She kissed Élise with noise and said, “You will be fine, because you have cheekbones,” and kissed Rafaël and said, “You will be fine because of your regret.” She was everything Renaud had described and also nothing like him, which is how affection tells its truth. In the compartment, she took out a tin of pins and a small jar of jam, which seemed to Élise like the perfect inventory for a person. “We will fix anything that is broken,” she said, and said nothing at all about rent or grit or deserving, which endeared her.

The train conducted them with authority into beginning. Fields performed their trick of changing without leaving. The sky didn’t bother with a thesis. People around them did the ordinary miracles of travel: a woman rode while making a to-do list that included the word happiness underlined twice, a boy slept in a position only boys will trust, a man made eye contact with his own reflection and seemed not to enjoy what he saw. Rafaël woke, ate a piece of bread as if bread were an invention he was proud of, and took her hand without looking at her, as if to warm a tool.

Paris received them with its usual unintimidated face. The station breathed them out. The taxi delivered them to a side street near the Carré, where trucks were being asked to be graceful and men were making good work look like chaos. Backstage, the corridor had that austere smell of clean floor and concentrated dreams. Names were being stuck to doors with tape; everywhere there was the rustling paper sound of people telling themselves they were prepared. Their dressing room was a square of light and a rack. It had a mirror framed with bulbs that told the truth and got away with it.

They rehearsed their walk from the wings to the mark, because walking is something people forget to study when they are trying to do something else. The stage, unlit, was indifferent to them in a way that comforted her. On the far side, two women practiced quiet violence in heels and did not fall. A small man with a moustache arranged trust into cables. A girl of seventeen, fragile and invincible, put on lashes as if she were laying a road.

At sound check, their brass rose like a hand in the dark and touched the upper air. The room answered with its own throat. Élise felt the small trick of the floor beneath its sprung astonishment and thought, absurdly, of soup coolers in school cafeterias with their inexhaustible vats. Anne pinned the dress in two secret places and gave the strap a last bit of encouragement that was technical and also, somehow, maternal. “You can eat a fruit,” Anne commanded, handing her a plum that did in fact taste like a small decision. “Not more. Your stomach will betray you.”

In the hour between knowing that something will happen and watching it happen, time sometimes goes to sit in the hallway and is replaced by a simpler cousin. They warmed their backs against a wall; they spoke in a pidgin of their own that did not mention the names of gods. Renaud texted a photo of the staff room with the caption the burnt has been replaced by the overboiled, which made her laugh while making her want to cry. Jules sent two words: Go well. She felt those words like two small weights in each pocket, the kind that keep a woman’s dress from flying up in wind.

When they were called, it was like stepping into a smell she had known all her life and could not name. Rafaël pressed his mouth once to the top of her head, which their arrangement both allowed and forbade. The lights did their mad insects dance and then settled; the audience became not one large animal but a discipline. She could hear the hush in its shoes. She put her foot on the mark that someone had taped where the world expects feet to go. The music began in exactly the place she had dreamed it would begin, and they did not lose each other even once.

There is, sometimes, a moment in dancing when the future does not exist and neither does the past, when the body is not a bank account or a mistake or a promise of something better, but only an engine beloved by the matter that surrounds it. She knew she had arrived in that place the way one knows one has closed a door properly—by the lack of any noise from it, by the way the wind ceases to be a question. Their last turn sharpened itself into relief. They ended not at the edge of a laugh but at the bottom of a breath, holding themselves open just long enough that the room could pour something into them that was not audible.

Applause is sometimes a polite rain, sometimes a weather one has no right to. This was the second kind. She looked at him, not because they shared their glory but because they shared the ridiculousness of being people who had asked for that glory aloud. They bowed as if it were a joke they had told themselves, and walked off like waiters who had not dropped a single glass.

Backstage had discovered them and began to make of them a story, the way backstages do because they cannot help themselves. A woman they had never met kissed her cheeks and immediately corrected her posture. A man in a hat told Rafaël that his line was clean and then explained to someone standing behind them what a clean line was. Anne dabbed a place on the dress that did not need dabbing and then hugged her so completely that for three seconds she could not have said what direction was.

They did not wait for the results the way normal people wait for weather. They said a sentence to each other three times—We did not die—and each time it meant something different. When the list went up in its bureaucratic font, she had to stand on her toes to see over a man’s shoulder. Their names were there, not at the top like the kind of story people adore, but not in the middle either, in that place where something like endurance lives. Third. The number looked compassionate and exacting, and it had the side benefit of not asking them to make speeches that would later humiliate them when they remembered what their mouths had done.

They took their trophy—gladiators as promised, so small and self-serious she loved them—and she felt the way she sometimes felt after kissing, which was that the world was nothing but a surface she now understood better. In the corner of the room, a girl cried for reasons that were either disappointment or the exhausting relief of not having to be hopeful for three hours. Rafaël leaned his forehead against hers and said nothing, and the nothing made her think of that year in the house with the sickroom noises and the nurses with ships for bodies, and of the first time she had taken a step toward music without asking anyone for permission.

On the train back, Anne slept with the sewing kit on her lap like a cat. Outside, the fields used up their remaining green. Rafaël held the trophy and made it walk along the edge of the window as if it were brave and on a ledge. They did not talk about money. They did not talk about the twelfth being not a miracle but a day, and the rent waiting like a dog behind a door. Anne woke just enough to say, “When you are very old you will remember the feel of your foot at the end of that turn and it will be worth half a lifetime of being sensible,” and fell back into sleep, trusting them to understand that sometimes a blessing arrives wearing a ridiculous hat.

At the station in Lyon, the air smelled of their own city’s mixture of bread and concrete. They carried the suitcase between them as if it were a cradle. In the taxi, there was a radio program that had invited a philosopher to talk about usefulness and art, and Élise laughed so abruptly that the driver looked at her in the mirror with the concern of a man who will have to clean the back seat if things go wrong. “It’s nothing,” she said, though it was, in fact, everything. “It is only that for once I have no argument to make.”

At home, the apartment greeted her with its water pipes’ frankness. She set the gladiators on the table and placed beside them the rent notice for the morning, and the little pile of cash that would join the rest and make good on a promise. She undressed with the carefulness one uses with borrowed things. In the mirror, she saw a woman whose hair had decided to be ridiculous and a line at the corner of her mouth she had not noticed yesterday. She put her palm to her sternum where the old woman in the fuchsia backpack had touched her and felt that bell still vibrating. Morning did not so much arrive as assemble itself out of serviceable parts, and she woke to find the light already doing its mild duty across the floorboards. The gladiators on the table had fallen in the night with a clink so modest that it had crossed into her dream and politely leaned against the wall there, and she righted them with two fingers and told them not to get ideas. The rent notice lay beside them like a cousin who enjoyed being correct. She washed her face at the sink where the mirror always made her a little more gray and a little more industrious, and she tied her hair back with the elastic she had found last week beneath a tram seat, because sometimes luck is simply deciding to pick something up that other people do not want. When she counted the envelope a final time, the bills seemed lighter for having already been promised, like children ready for a school trip who are determined not to cause trouble.

In the stairwell, the damp smelled like a noncommittal apology, and the neighbor’s boy had left the bicycle in a position that suggested optimism about gravity. On the second floor landing, Madame Hanriot’s door was open a crack, which in that building meant either catastrophe or company, and when she knocked lightly she heard the television’s underfed chatter and the urgent concentration of a cat demanding to be let out of a closed room. The landlord appeared with her glasses on a chain and that expression of someone who has never been late for anything except, perhaps, joy, and Élise held out the envelope with both hands as if it were a ceremony they had prepared for together. They did the little arithmetic aloud, for the god of exactness, and then Madame Hanriot surprised her by glancing past her shoulder into the corridor and saying, almost confidingly, that when she had been nineteen she had once driven to Marseille on a whim to see a man dance on a table, and that it had been a great waste of petrol and a very important expenditure all the same.

“You don’t dance,” the older woman said then, with the investigating curiosity of someone who has seen shoes and shoulders but prefers to be told.

“I dance enough to have to ask you for the twelfth,” said Élise, and the smile they shared was the kind women share when they have both kept an account no one else has access to. At the end of the exchange, Madame Hanriot put three euros into Élise’s palm with the crispness of a notary and said they were from the meter downstairs which had begun to work properly again, and the absurdity of the tiny refund made them both laugh a little longer than the amount deserved, because laughter at such a scale is an excuse to like each other without committing to anything.

The walk to the collège tasted of tin and bakery, and at the corner by the butcher the fennel smell was practicing for better weather. The school’s front door, painted a municipal green that resisted sophistication, had been propped with a chair, which meant something had broken and custodians were dealing with it by allowing air to pretend to be a hinge. In the staff room, the coffee wore an expression of resigned virtue; Renaud had been beaten to the machine by someone unimaginative, and was stirring a small tub of yogurt with the philosophical attention people give to white substances in early hours. When she lifted the trophy out of her bag, letting the gladiators inspect the crumbs of chalk and the folded newspaper that enumerated tragedies briskly, he made a sound that was nearly a curse and then kissed the top of one small bronze head with a flourish that was entirely unserious and entirely sincere.

“You brought Rome to us,” he said, and set the figurine on the shelf that held, among other things, three ceramic owls and a plant that had decided to convert dust into a lifestyle. “We are an empire again. Now the coffee may burn with dignity.”

She told it all quickly, the way one tells news that has already turned into memory, because otherwise it begins to tell you. She told the hush and the brass and the way the end had felt like holding a breath she could finally release into a room that understood her. Renaud, who would have mocked any word that admitted to being noble, kept his face serious for the duration and then, perhaps realizing he had managed to be grave for too long, announced that an electrician had been reluctant to fix the photocopier because he claimed it had ambitions, and that therefore today’s copies might come out like poetic fragments, which would suit her perfectly. She laughed, and beneath the laughter she felt the small animal of fatigue curl itself against her ribs in a way that felt affectionate rather than predatory, as if her body had decided to protect her by asking only for a chair.

Camille arrived at break with hair that had decided to be bigger than her face, breathless not from running but from being awake in a world that had finally given her two poems. She handed over the pages with a solemnity that warned against jokes and then hovered, pretending to read a poster about a debate club. The first poem had been cut cleanly where it had needed it, not like a martyr but like an adult, and the line about the jacket had, as promised, been given a room of its own, where it had invited a lamp and a silent rug. They talked in the back of the classroom where the light made people honest, about what happens when a metaphor gets tired, about what generosity between lines might look like, and about the kind of bravery it takes to discard something perfectly written because it has hidden the thing you were trying to say. Camille’s mother had written at the top in a pinched hand that she did not understand the thing about the father and the jacket, and they agreed that often the people being written about must be allowed to be wrong.

The day put on its clothes and stood in front of her the way days always do in schools, stubbornly practical in their shoelaces and their whistles. During the third hour, the headmaster arrived at her door with the dignified flurry of a minor official whose world has developed a leak, and asked, in that way he had of prefacing decisions with the word “unfortunately,” whether she might, what with her success in things pertaining to rhythm, consider organizing a weekly club for students who bore a dangerous quantity of fidgets. There would be no money, of course, except in the budget where money is kept for things seen to be desirable by committees, and perhaps if she wrote a grant application, which was the secular prayer these days, something might be arranged. She kept her mouth from saying something that would taste good and then upset her stomach, and said instead that she would think and draft and find a way to make a floor remember feet. He smiled with relief and moved on like a trolley.

After classes, the school emptied itself in a performance that had been rehearsed for decades, and the courtyard let go its racket and then became a place where a solitary ball sought a friend and a woman with a clipboard pretended to be more official than she felt. She took the trophy to show the library, because the librarian loved objects and thought books were better when they had to share the air with things that had weight. He placed it between a dictionary that knew too much and a glass jar of marbles that he used to explain randomness to children who understood it intuitively, and he asked her to write a small label. The word gladiator, handwritten, struck her as both faintly ridiculous and correct, which is probably what the truth looks like when it wears a costume.

She went home the long way, because she could, because the rent had been paid and the world had not punished her for being absurd. The river was in a green mood and the sky had decided to practice being larger than it needed to be, and on the embankment an old man fed a piece of bread to a dog so tenderly that the bread seemed to become a new organ. The fuchsia backpack appeared to her peripherally before its owner did, as some objects announce their people, and the old woman from the studio called out to her as if greeting a niece she had briefly misplaced. They stood together watching damp swans be overpraised by tourists, and the woman told her that she had once learned every step of a Cha-Cha in a single night because she was trying to forget a man whose name began with M and who had owned a bakery and a darkness. It had worked for three months, which is a result most religions would envy.

At the apartment, the silence was a kind one, and she set down her bag, unpinned her hair, and did the small domestic trick of making a sandwich feel like an accomplishment. The trophy looked patient and foolish on the table, and when she brushed it with her thumb the dust there gave up its place generously. There was an email from Madame Giraud, whose consonants always felt like a firm hand, congratulating them again and attaching a small, polite request for a two-sentence quote to be used in a local write-up, and she wrote something that she hoped would make her future self less likely to wince. She thanked the stage, which is a sentimental thing to do, and she thanked the people who had invented the screws that made it possible for boards to pretend to be silence.

Rafaël sent a message that was a photograph of his wrist with a blister the size of a coin and the caption my kingdom for a glove, and she sent back instructions about warm water and ridiculously expensive creams and he replied with a picture of a tin of old-fashioned salve that he claimed could cure both leaks and heartbreak. They met at the studio anyway, because you do not stop touching the door just because it opened once, and there they practiced not the piece but the habit. He did the thing where he put his hand at the small of her back without demand, the way one makes a promise to a wall when one is drunk, and she felt that sore triumphant place in her body where triumph has left a bruise and decided to name it. They tried a step they had abandoned months ago because it had made her feel as if she were a coin being tossed into an uncertain hat, and this time it felt like a leaf returning to a tree; they kept it and were possibly ridiculous for doing so.

They argued with pleasure about what would come next, as people argue when the thing just done has protected them from the future for a day or two. He wanted to sign them up for a spring festival on a square where the stones had seen men behead fish and women argue the price of apricots, while she wanted to spend a month doing nothing except finding a way to teach Camille to stand with her shoulders where shoulders are supposed to be. He called her a saint with bad knees and she called him an apostle with bandaged wrists, and the boy with earbuds looked up from his acrobatics long enough to grin and then go back to letting gravity teach him and ignoring it anyway.

In the late evening, when the city begins to withdraw its offers and ask instead for stories, she stood at her window and watched two men carry a sofa across the street without the help of kindness, and she thought how some objects pass through lives like ministers and others like friends. Jules’ message arrived with a pause built into it, as if it had sat by itself on a bench for a while before deciding whether to cross a street. He said he would be in Lyon on Friday with the children, that he had promised them a museum and the funicular, and that if she had time they would like to see her face in the large. He did not mention the word sorry again, which pleased her because repetition makes apology cheap, and he did not threaten to bring a lecture, which pleased her because she was not a child and had no desire to audition for that role. She wrote back that she would meet them near the fountain where pigeons practiced being citizens, and she imagined his daughters counting lions and being unmoved by history.

Sleep found her like an afterthought, and she welcomed it like a lover who has learned to knock. In the morning, her ankle did the small complaint that meant she had treated it like a democracy and it had preferred a benevolent dictatorship, and she promised it sympathy in the form of warm water and attention. The day’s lessons involved the subjunctive, which made everyone briefly wish for death and then become dignified, and in the second class a boy asked why one needed to talk about what might not be true, and she answered that without it no one could write a love letter or threaten revenge or imagine their lives into a shape they could bear, and he looked at her with that face children sometimes have when they ask a question for one reason and receive an answer that grows a new room in their house.

In the afternoon, she went to the headmaster with her draft of a club that did not want to be called a club because that word had sat too long under posters with clip-art. She proposed, instead, a laboratory of movement where feet and sentences could conspire, and he, perhaps unexpectedly, set down his pen and admitted that as a child he had once wished to be a tightrope walker until his father, a man of lists, had convinced him that the world required more men who could sign documents. They worked out a schedule between them like a truce, and she left with the sense of having smuggled a small contraband across a border that had been left, for a moment, unguarded.

On Thursday evening, the apartment of her childhood sent its ghost in the form of a smell that did not belong to her building—boiled chicken and a kind of institutional orange—and she stood very still until it passed, because memory is a bully until you refuse to give it attention. She took the bus to the shop with the dress to bring the woman a small plant wrapped in paper because gratitude is better worn than spoken, and found the counter attended by a young man with shoulders who called for his mother with the composed irritation of a person who has watched thread his whole life. The woman emerged with a pin in her mouth and kissed both of Élise’s cheeks without removing the pin, then nodded at the dress where it hung with an expression she seemed to believe reflected well upon herself. They joked about the strap’s behavior onstage, as if it had been a teenager, and in parting the woman said that the dresses that did the least work often did the most good, which Élise tried to hear as philosophy and not as evidence against her own desire for instruments that glitter.

Friday took on the shape of a plan. Jules texted that they were on the 10:12 and that the children had eaten something sweet that had converted their bones to air, and she prepared herself to receive her nieces with a face that would make them believe in aunts. At the square, the pigeons did their municipal business and the fountain performed its stately nonsense, and the two girls approached with the motion of people who have taught their shoes to love running more than they love feet. The older was lanky and suspicious and the younger was a small justice of the peace; both attached themselves to her waist with the generous greed of family, and Jules arrived with that smile he uses when he does not know how to be forgiven and a day-old beard that made him look like his father, which made her want to kiss and hit him in quick succession.

They did the things people do when they have not quarrelled about anything that can be fixed by doing things. They rode the funicular and pretended to be unimpressed and failed, and the girls loved a painting because it had a dog in it, and in the cramped lunch hour they ate sandwiches that hurt the gums and pretended they did not, and Jules told her a story about his youngest refusing to accept that rain existed because it had not yet rained on her birthday, and she told him a story about Anne’s sewing kit containing a jam that tasted of confession. Between the jokes there were small plazas where quiet could stand, and in one of those he said he should not have written the sentence about watching her hurt herself, that he had meant he did not know how to help and that watching someone you love not be saved by what they love is the sort of puzzle that ruins men who like solutions.

“I am not a problem,” she said, and they both smiled at the silliness of the sentence because everything is a problem if you look at it from the right angle, and then she took his hand, which was no longer the boy’s hand she remembered and not yet the old man’s hand she did not want to consider, and squeezed once. The girls climbed on the lion’s stone back and declared war on an invisible army, which is the sort of war adults ought to have to fight daily for exercise.

At the studio that evening, she and Rafaël gave themselves the luxury of dancing badly on purpose, which is to say they let themselves laugh at their feet and taught their shoulders that grace is sometimes a matter of timing and sometimes a matter of consenting to be ridiculous. A salsa night had been announced by a flyer with a photograph of a couple whose lips seemed unsure whether to belong to their own faces, and they considered joining the crowd that would later call names of steps to one another as if ordering drinks.
