In the end they stayed in their familiar square, because even fêtes can be a burden, and because among their own mirrors and their own benches they did not have to be received by strangers who might decide to love them for the wrong reasons.

Saturday was the kind of day that hides a needle in a cushion. The morning made itself easy, and she did the useful nothing of errands until the afternoon asked for an accounting. She had promised herself she would not touch the envelope of leftover cash because promises are an architecture and she was tired of rebuilding, but then a bill arrived with the urgency of red ink and the postman’s apology, and she sat with the paper in her hand long enough to give it the shape of something that could kill her if she let it land. She called the company, which presented itself as an idea and a menu, and waited through a version of a song that someone had chosen for its ability to be unnoticed. When a person finally arrived at the other end of the line, breathing had never seemed so significant. The human voice reduced the threat in the paper by half, which is what voices do, and together they negotiated a delay and a reduction and an agreement that she would call again before the calendar did. She hung up and felt exemplary, then immediately humiliated by the smallness of the achievement, and she went to the window and watched the street for a while until a man with a ladder taught her that balance is not a metaphor and then made it one by nearly falling and laughing.

Late in the day, a message from Giraud arrived like a note slid across a table by someone competent. There would be, she wrote with the tidy optimism of a schedule, a small showcase at the end of the month for those who had placed, and a short interview filmed for social channels whose hunger she would not insult by underestimating. If they wished to be included, they need only say yes and bring the dress that had caused a backstage debate among the seamstresses about bias and idiocy. Élise read the email twice, then a third time with one hand on her chest where the bell had been touched and told the air that she would, yes, continue to say yes because saying no had never saved her from anything worth being saved from. She texted Rafaël, who replied first with caution because he had learned to distrust the moment after victory, and then with a photograph of his shoes lined up as if they had somewhere to be.

When Sunday came, the city allowed itself a certain laxity in the angles of things. She went to the market and bought two apples that had decided to be old in an elegant way, and a small fish that looked like a confession and would later be delicious with lemon and a stubborn herb. She ran into the librarian buying mushrooms and they discussed the trophy’s placement as if it were a student with needs. On her way home, she paused by the poster for the finals and this time did not look away immediately, allowing herself to see the strangers in their good architecture, and then allowing herself to be a little bored of them because she had come to believe in the usefulness of boredom as a weapon against envy.

That afternoon she wrote her grant application like a woman writing a love letter to a desk. She used the words people like to see when they must give money they would rather hoard: outreach, community, resilience, inclusivity, scaffolding, measurable. She made it honest where it could bear it and made it clever where honesty would bore, and when she had finished she read it aloud to the plants that had never asked anything of her but water and a certain dignity, and sent it, then stood and practiced not thinking about whether anyone would read the thing she had written. She had learned, over the years, that one cannot live awaiting replies without becoming a person whose face has no patience left in it, and she had decided, perhaps foolishly and certainly stubbornly, that she would rather have lines that showed the work of laughing.

In the evening, because celebration is a muscle you must use or lose, she put on the dress that was not the dress and went to the bar near the river where an accordion had taken up residence, and there she let herself be taken into three dances with a stranger whose hands were honest and whose breath was noisy, and into a fourth with a woman who led like a promise that wanted to be forgiven. Around her, the city made noises that had nothing to do with her and everything to do with what it means to be in a place with others, and she thought of the girls at the studio with their knees like breadsticks and the boys with their earbud catechisms, and of the way Camille had said she felt like a thief and a little like God. She went home with her ankles doing their commentary, and in the kitchen she ate the fish with lemon and the honest herb and let the juice run onto her wrist, and decided that the evening had been a small success in the direction of not asking every hour to give her a reason for itself.

On Monday, the laboratory of movement became not a plan but a door someone had opened, and six children walked through it as if they had been waiting outside for weeks. They came in pairs and alone, with shyness like a scarf around the neck and bravado like a hat worn too low. She moved the desks back, which made the room look briefly unemployed, and put on not music but a metronome that had once belonged to a piano teacher who wore pearls in solidarity with order. They began with the scandalous instruction to stand still and feel where their feet were, which made two boys giggle and a girl look dangerous, and then she had them walk to the far wall and back in silence as if the floor were someone who needed to be convinced. Someone asked if there would be prizes and she said yes, but not the kind that glitter, and she did not apologize for being mystical because children live in a world where mysticism is the only politics that makes sense.

They played the game where one person closes their eyes and another leads with the lightest touch of a finger on a sleeve, and when one of the boys tried to turn it into a slapstick, the girl from 5B who carried herself like a question mark said, without malice, that this was serious, and the boy made the face of someone discovering that seriousness is not a punishment. At the end, sweaty from nothing and flushed from permission, they sat cross-legged and she asked them to say one true thing about their bodies that was not an insult, and at first they resisted and then a small stampede of exhausted truth arrived—my arms are good at carrying, my back hurts when I lie, my feet know the way home—and she felt that bell in her chest move like a creature in a well.

The week smoothed itself into something like a promise that one could be borne. She and Rafaël met in the evenings and developed the kind of confidentiality about exhaustion that people develop when they trust one another with ugliness. He came one night with a story about the job in Oullins in which a pipe had confessed to being older than the men responsible for it, and she came another with a story about a mother whose eyes had asked permission to cry while her mouth asked for grammar exercises for a child who ate paper, and between stories they moved, because that is what bodies do when words have run out of their usefulness.

In the small hours on Friday, waking because some neighbor’s door had decided to be enthusiastic, she lay in the exact position she had lay in when she was ten and believed the ceiling must need her eyes to stay up, and she listened for the details that separate one insomnia from another. The city sent a siren and a laugh; her radiator rehearsed its clucks; a couple upstairs negotiated a silence; a cat on a wall decided against risk. She thought of the girl who had cried backstage and of Anne’s jam and of the train with its confident face, and of Jules and his daughters with their lion-conquering, and of the old woman’s hand at her sternum, and she began to imagine the room where the showcase would be, and the angle at which she would carry her shoulder into the second turn so that the strap would not argue, and the exact moment at which she would find Rafaël’s palm and let herself be led away from the fact that she would always have to ask some version of a stranger to trust her.

By the time the alarm performed its tiny marvel, her mind had already flown three circuits of a day, and still a kind of contentment was available to her as she dressed, in the form of a sweater that had not yet decided to betray her at the elbows and the knowledge that she had paid what she owed and was not being hunted by a piece of paper. She put the gladiators on the shelf beside the cheap potted plant she had once bought in pity and which now insisted upon being a tree, and she said good morning to both of them with a ridiculous courtesy, and then she went out to find the world in the mood for what she could bear to offer.Chapter 6

The week that followed put on an ordinary coat and then found a rose in its pocket, and the simple discovery made everything else smell faintly of patience. Mornings were back to being assemblies of damp scarves and low clouds with opinions, the Saône practicing its restrained breathing between the stone shoulders that disciplined it, and her feet learned the winter route again, which involved exactly two puddles, a bakery window with a charitable éclair, and the butcher’s fennel that insisted on appearing in every season as if it had an appointment with her lungs. The little gladiators took to their shelf in the staff room with an air of having been sent ahead to reserve a table for victory, and the plant beside them, encouraged by this brass companionship, produced one surprised leaf that Renaud claimed to have coaxed with Handel and a speech about excellence. She took pleasure in the stiff routines because they allowed her to hide bits of brightness inside them like postcards slipped into thick books, and because after the kind of night where applause still lives in the body as a new organ, one needs somewhere to put the organ down for a while without breaking it.

The movement laboratory became a regular appointment, which is to say it became complicated in the way commitments become complicated as soon as they acquire their own furniture. At the second session, a very small boy named Farid, who was the size of an object one might place deliberately on a bookshelf, arrived with a letter from his mother signed with five different loops and an insistence that he would not, could not, should not remove his shoes in public, and she wrote back in the elegant neutral of a teacher’s note that he could keep his shoes on so long as he promised to learn to feel his feet without anyone else seeing him do it. The girl from 5B who had looked dangerous last week arrived wearing defiance that had been ironed, and when the boys made jokes about touching with a fingertip she suggested, with a perfectly pleasant voice, that anyone who giggled at permission would not be included in the part where the music came in. By the end of the hour, the floor had given up its indifference, and when she told them to walk as if the world were listening and they were saying something true with their knees, they tried, and in trying made a sound that could not be heard except by the dust.

At school as in life, small accommodations took on the look of progress. The headmaster sent a message with the kind of subject line one writes to oneself in hope—funding possibility, movement—and she met him in his office where a bowl of citrus tried to make a philosophy of freshness. Together they coaxed her grant application into a form that did not scare committees and did not disgust her, adding a paragraph about how bodies that understand themselves tend to harm others less, and subtracting a sentence she had loved about the way a metronome can act as a friend. He told her about a boy he had once taught who had taken up the bassoon to avoid violence, and she told him about a girl who had traded silence for a step, and between them the room acquired a temperate hope, which is the only kind that lasts. When she left, he pressed three photocopy tokens into her palm as if they were coins to cross a river, and she thanked him with more feeling than the coins deserved because, often, it is not the object but the shared belief in it that makes it holy.

Rafaël, meanwhile, acquired an injury with theatrical modesty. At the site near Oullins, a coil of copper, affronted by its own stubbornness, had snapped back and found his wrist with the unerring nose of humiliation, leaving a half-moon bruise that looked like punctuation. He texted a photograph of it that made the hand appear both heroic and ridiculous, and when she met him at the studio he offered up the offended limb with a comic solemnity that made her want to blow on it as if he were a child and she possessed a mother’s breath. The injury was not ruinous, but it asked for respect, and respect in dance is often the difference between pretended leadership and actual listening. They learned, therefore, a slightly different grammar of their partnership, one in which his left hand’s insistence softened into a question and her back, which had long practiced polite obedience, took on a little more decision, and it occurred to her that this was a lesson about more than bones and sinew, though she did not say it because people become unkind when they are offered metaphors about themselves before they have asked.

The showcase that Giraud had promised became a date that sat up straight on the calendar, and the email with its unmatched fonts and its enthusiastic list of “opportunities for visibility” did its best to be both a promise and a threat. She filled out the release forms with a pen that had survived the lives of five faculties, and tried not to be too amused by the phrase “by participating you agree to be seen,” which seemed to her both honest and indecent. Anne wrote to say she would be there with a needle and an opinion, and in the same breath asked, in her majestic way, if she might borrow Élise’s kitchen on Sunday to make a jam that required the kind of patience none of her lovers could be trusted to demonstrate. “I will pay with sugar and a counsel you will not take,” Anne wrote, and Élise laughed in the empty room and sent back her address like a performance schedule. It occurred to her that one of the great luxuries of being an adult is deciding which fervent instructions to disobey.

Camille brought both poems and a face that had discovered that ambition does not always look like a horse one can ride; sometimes it looks like a room that has not been aired. They sat with the pages and the invisible lamp they moved between them whenever they used words like tenderness and necessary, and a disagreement about whether brackets should be allowed to exist in a poem took on the contour of a debate about whether a person ought to narrate their own forgiveness while doing the forgiving. Camille, who had a mother with many sentences living inside her and a father who had become a parenthesis, argued for the brackets, and Élise argued for their absence while confessing to a private love of parentheses, and in the end they invented a compromise that was not really a compromise but an invitation to write two poems again. “You are exhausting,” Camille declared with a smile that forecast a life of specific insistence, and Élise told her that exhaustion was simply the name for the feeling of having lived inside one’s work for a while without opening a window, and that it could be survived with fruit and laughter.

One afternoon, after a lesson in which the subjunctive convinced several children that French was unfair for having invented a mood that punished people for dreaming aloud, she found herself at the cemetery without having planned it, which is often how one comes to see the dead when one intends only a longer walk. The rows of names did the quiet labor of reminding the living that other people have had days, and more than once her feet stopped and her eyes read someone else’s age as if it were a price she might be willing to pay. Her mothers lay under a stone they had chosen together when the younger one was still convinced of a long career in laughter, and the older had insisted on something plain, because even her grief had been allergic to ostentation. She sat on the low wall and told them the news the way a child tells invisible friends a secret, not because she expected an answer but because the act itself made the air less empty. She told them about Paris in the voice she reserved for things that tried to be both miraculous and bureaucratic, she told them about the lab and the boy who had learned not to giggle at being led, she told them about Jules and his apology that had been short and sincere, and then she told them about the rent and how very grown she had felt handing over an envelope like a person in a film. The wind was industrious, moving low branches and small regrets, and when she stood she felt lighter in exactly the way one does when a bag has been taken off the shoulder and forgotten for half a block.

The interview for the showcase was scheduled for a Thursday night in a room that had been a canteen and now tried to be a studio with the help of three cheap lights and a young woman with a microphone that had opinions. The questions were the kind that want to be short answers and become long if you happen to be honest, and the cameraman, who had hair arranged like a decision, asked them to be more emotional and then less, and then to try something in which they felt “connected” though not “dependent,” and she and Rafaël exchanged the look of two people who have shared an absurdity before and agreed silently to behave. When it was her turn to speak alone, she said a sentence about the way movement had been the boat she had not known she had built, and another about how teaching sometimes felt like taking dictation from a group mind that did not know its own beauty, and when she began to say a third that involved the word salvation she stopped herself because she did not want to frighten the microphone. Rafaël, in his turn, admitted to having learned tenderness from wood and wire, and said, with a gentle bravado, that a good lead is a conversation and a poor one an order, and Élise looked at him and did not say that she had been waiting to hear that from a man since she was the size of an adjective.

On Friday, Jules arrived with the girls again because they had discovered that a funicular is a machine that can be loved like a pet, and this time he brought their mother—their mother by virtue of the children and the kitchen table, not because the universe had given her any paper to prove it—who had been the cord around which his life had been braided for a decade. She was a woman with a surgical humor and an unreasonable kindness toward chairs, and she received Élise with a scrutiny that was affectionate and a little dangerous, as if she were measuring her not for a dress but for a future conversation that would include the word stubborn. Over coffees that behaved like citizens, they spoke about the stupid magnificence of cities, and about the school’s decision to cut field trips, and then the woman took the girls to watch a street musician whose instrument accepted griefs for money, and Jules and Élise were left in a square of afternoon in which they could afford to finish a sentence. He told her he had lain awake the night before thinking about the line in Camille’s poem about the jacket, because even though he did not know the girl he had recognized in it the look their father used to have when he came home from a day spent selling people the idea of certainty and could not find a place for his own uncertainty to sit. She told him she had dreamed of a room full of her mother’s hair and that the dream had not been cruel, only insistent, and he put his hand on the table and she put hers over it and for a moment it was as if they had managed to be their own parents and forgive themselves for the hours they had not managed to save.

The dress behaved in rehearsal as if it had been raised well. Anne, possessed by a benevolent tyranny, pinned it into obedience with such efficiency that the garment seemed grateful, and she left Élise’s kitchen smelling like sugar that had reconsidered its life and a citrus that had decided it could not go on unless it was boiled. They ate bread with a jam that tasted like a decision not to apologize, and Anne told stories about stages that had refused to behave and how one must be polite to a board even when it creaks insults, and she gave Élise a small pin in the shape of a star with one crooked point, saying in a voice that did not mind being theatrical that it had belonged to her grandmother who had danced once in Poland because a man in a hat had told her he could not promise to love her but could promise to watch with kindness. The star was not valuable and its crookedness made it look as if it had survived an argument, and Élise pinned it to the inside of the dress where only she would know it lived, because there are talismans one must wear close to skin and not advertise to fate.

The night of the showcase arrived with an edge, the way music halls collect weather around their doors. The Carré had decided to be generous, and backstage the seamstresses conducted their perennial debate about whether bias cuts were the invention of a genius or a saboteur, and several men made it their duty to count cables in different directions. There was a small mishap, because stages have their sense of humor, and twenty minutes before they were called a portion of the lights executed a meaningful flicker and then gave up, forcing a man with a calm moustache to become a hero with a ladder while someone else delivered a speech to the fuse box about perseverance. Anne padded about with her pins like a person charged with keeping planets in their orbits, and when the stage manager came to tell them that the lights could be persuaded to be faithful but not entirely obedient, they looked at each other and agreed in that quiet way that they would dance like people who have learned at last how to be looked at in the dark.

They were given a slot early, which meant the audience’s attention was still thirsty and not yet sophisticated with expectations. The music came in clean and then disappeared once, as if embarrassed to be caught assisting, and the darkness in that moment was not complete but sufficient to make them more important to themselves, and in the half-light she could see the edge of the stage like a sentence that had been cut short and had to be guessed. He tightened the connection at her back by a shade, and she let her ribs listen to his breath, and together they made the adjustments that all intimacy requires when the room changes its mind about permission. The last turn, their friend and their treachery, arrived at exactly the right moment and accepted their offering of ankles and trust, and when the lights returned entirely at the end, as if apologizing for their earlier whim, they found the two of them in that posture just after the bow where one is both naked and armored, and the applause did not have the frantic stupidity of competition; it had instead the texture of relief, like water after salt.

In the quiet room afterward where the recorded interviews would be spliced into each other and uploaded to hungry places, a young woman from a local channel asked her what she would say to her younger self if she could go back and advise her before she decided to begin late. She said, carefully and then not careful at all, that she would tell the girl that lateness is a kind of style and that shame is a poor instructor, and that if you wait to be invited you will spend your life holding your breath in doorways, and the girl with the microphone made a noise of polite enthusiasm and then a real noise, the kind people make when an answer reminds them of a thing they have been pretending not to want. Later, when the video appeared in a corner of the internet that was not inhospitable, she watched herself in the brightness and felt both deadly earnest and ridiculous, and she decided to love herself in the clip with the same practiced generosity she extended to the children when their mouths forgot how to be brave.

The week after, a man from the municipal cultural center called with a question that sounded like an opportunity wearing comfortable shoes. Would she, he asked with the brisk humility of someone who has been told “no” very often, consider leading a short series of movement sessions for adults who had misplaced their bodies somewhere in the years between chores and catastrophe? There was not much money, there was never much money, but there was enough to buy peaches for a month and to pay for a pair of shoes that did not make the knees regret hope, and the classes would be on a Tuesday evening in a room that had once been used to teach circle dances and then used to store chairs and would now be pressed into service as mercy. She said yes because the part of her that makes lists nodded and because the part of her that lives in ankles clapped, and then she hung up and let herself be foolish in the hallway, weaving between the shadow of the coat rack and the washing machine with a move that had no name and did not need one.

At school, the movement laboratory discovered that children enjoy teaching more than being taught, and she spent a joyful session watching a boy instruct a girl in the art of not flinching when someone places a hand between your shoulder blades to tell you which way the music goes, a lesson that should be taught in every school by law. The librarian moved the gladiators to a higher shelf because a younger class had tried to use them as chess pieces and invented, in the process, a war between verbs and nouns that ended with the verb fleeing on a dinosaur, and he asked her if she wanted the trophy back and she told him to keep it hostage a little longer so that she might collect the pleasure of seeing it during passing moments when she needed to remember that brass can be a kind of kindness. Renaud was still in love with the idea of being of use, and began, spontaneously, to bring her small presents of competence—a sharpened pencil at the exact time she lost her own, a photocopy that had collated itself, a cap on a pen that matched—until she told him, with an affection that bordered on gratitude, that she could survive without being rescued so long as he continued to tell her stories in which he, by accident, became a hero in the medley of administrative incompetences.

There was, of course, a bill that wanted to be the antagonist in a story that did not require one, and on a Tuesday afternoon the envelope that arrived with the modest thud of bureaucracy demanded money for something she had not known she was using—some line of internet that had been attached to something else, or a charge that had been explained in a tone that frightened her into agreement. She felt the old vertigo and sat on the edge of the bed to make the room sit down with her, then did the grown thing of calling and waiting and negotiating without crying, and in the silence between the hold music and the human voice she recited to herself the declaration Anne had made about old boards and the way one must be polite even to the things that ruin your heels. When a person finally answered, he turned out to be a boy who loved football and who admitted, after three minutes, that the fee was designed to discourage despair and could be removed if one remembered to ask, and she thanked him so sincerely that he laughed and told her she could call back any time to talk about chickens, which she decided not to analyze.

On a Thursday that tasted like metal, she watched the video of the showcase at her desk between classes, and a girl who was supposed to be finding the subjunctive instead found the clip and, seeing her teacher moving like someone with permission, put her hand to her mouth and asked, in a whisper that had disobedience and admiration in it, how one acquired such a back. “By carrying too many books and then deciding to carry none,” she said, and the girl nodded as if this were practical. A parent wrote a polite message asking whether the club encouraged “expressiveness that might distract from examination rigor,” and she wrote back that expressive people tend to survive examinations with their souls intact and that a child who can stand still when asked will not, in fact, ruin a classroom by discovering the metronome that lives in their ribs. The parent responded with a line about budgets and standards that had surely been copied from a publication, and Élise put the phone down and went to the lab and taught six children how to walk a line without looking at their feet.

On Saturday morning, the cultural center held a small orientation that involved pastries behaving like ambassadors, and she sat in a circle of folding chairs with a shy retired dancer who had a knee like an old door, a man who had come because he had been told by a doctor to “reconnect” and had decided that the word, if not the act, appealed to him, a young woman whose hair was a protest and who wore anger like a borrowed coat, and two mothers who wanted to discover whether there was space beneath duty for breath. They began by sitting silently until someone laughed because silence in groups is offensive to the human appetite, and then she spoke about what the floor asked for from them and what it did not, and about what bravery looks like when no one is watching, and then they stood and took four steps and stopped and took two steps back, and in the disorder of the small moves she saw people being generous with their injuries and with their pride. At the end, the man with the knee asked if the exit would be painful, and she told him yes, but that the pain would teach them the way home, and he nodded as if he had been waiting for someone to make even one promise that was not an advertisement.

That evening, a rain came that thought itself more important than it was, and the city became glossy and melancholy in the way of things that have performed this trick too often and still get away with it. She and Rafaël practiced the section they had abandoned years ago because it had humiliated them in front of a mirror, and this time the mirror, having watched them suffer other humiliations with grace, decided to be cordial. He told her about a cousin who had phoned from a job site in Toulouse where they needed men who could be trusted to find leaks that did not want to be found, and she heard in his voice the preparation for leaving that some men carry around like a toolkit. He did not ask her to tell him not to go; she did not tell him she would be angry if he stayed out of habit; they simply measured the space between his wrist and the idea of a new city, and then they danced the kind of practice that says we will survive this conversation later without a stage.

On Sunday, the old woman with the fuchsia backpack appeared like an appointment kept by fate, her bun tighter than her arguments, and insisted on taking Élise for a coffee she could not afford and for which she paid with a grand gesture that made the coins look like theater. She told Élise she had once had a pin that brought her luck until she lost it on the bus to Charpennes and that afterward everything in her life had continued as normal and yet a small door had remained closed for a long time because objects sometimes carry the permission that people refuse to give themselves. Élise told her about the crooked star and the woman who had bequeathed it, and the old woman, pleased as if twins had discovered each other in a shop, took her hand without warning and pressed her palm to the table and tapped once with her finger where the bell lived. “It is still ringing,” she said in a tone that admitted an almost superstitious satisfaction, and Élise, surprised to find that this assessment comforted her, agreed.

At the end of the month, when the cultural center sent a poster with her name in a font that had not been made to flatter the poor and the brave, she stuck it to her refrigerator with a magnet shaped like a pear and felt, for a moment, the kind of pride that does not brag because it is too busy preparing the chairs. She had the laboratory on Mondays, the adults on Tuesdays, her own practice on Fridays because Wednesday and Thursday belonged to being tired, and on Saturdays the invigilations would come like slow trains, and she could see a season arranged not like a trap but like a scaffolding. In the spaces left between, there were children who asked if the future could be written in a tense they liked, and a brother who was learning how to owe and be owed affection without turning that into mathematics, and a man who might go to Toulouse and whose wrist had healed sufficiently for him to be negligent of it again, and a city that persisted in being a place where women could walk at night with a small fear and a small joy and arrive home with both.

When sleep was slow to find her, she lay on her back and let her ankles tell the story of the day to her knees while the radiator rehearsed its jokes, and she thought about the problem of deserving and the solution of persistence, and about how sometimes a life feels like a hall that refuses your shoes and then, by way of some administrative error or grace, admits you with an apology and a chair. She did not make plans bigger than a month because everything larger than that has always felt like hubris and budget, but she let herself picture a year in which the lab survived inspection and the adults laughed at their own seriousness and she bought lemons without looking at their price, and in which she allowed herself to imagine that the bell at her sternum would continue to ring not with the clang of alarms but with the low, friendly insistence of a town clock that knows everyone’s names. Outside, a bus sighed and a woman laughed at a joke the night had told her, and the sound slid in through the small opening in the window and made a place for itself on the shelf beside the gladiators, and she slept with her hand on the crooked star through the thin fabric as if she were a girl who had smuggled home a secret and intended, stubbornly, to keep it.Chapter 8

Winter did not ask permission; it clamped itself over the city with the quiet certainty of a lid finding its pot, and the Saône took on that particular fatigue that makes water look like metal. In the mornings, the damp became less tender, choosing instead to be factual; her scarf learned a new tightness and the fennel behind the butcher turned suddenly medicinal, as if it had been hired for its virtues. The bell at her sternum did not stop; it lowered its note until it could be felt in the bones of her wrists when she lifted her mug. On a Tuesday that had more gray than hours, Rafaël told her in the studio with his hands at his pockets as if he had been instructed to behave himself that the job in Toulouse had turned from rumor to train ticket. He spoke with that deliberate cheerfulness some men build when they have dragged a decision across every room in their heads, and she listened with the particular kind of attention she reserves for people she is determined not to make into enemies. “Six weeks,” he said, and the number was both small and unbearable. They considered, in the way dancers measure distances without moving, how far six weeks is for a body that is used to being found by the same palm between the shoulder blades, and then they began to talk about times and trains, and who would take care of the plants in his kitchen, and whether he should try the place with the inexpensive rooms near the station or accept his cousin’s offer of a couch and a constant argument.

At the collège, the laboratory acquired a visitor’s chair and a visitor to sit in it, because the headmaster had mentioned the word “oversight” in a meeting and the word had grown fruit. The woman from the committee wore a navy dress that had been asked to look impartial and a scarf that had been asked to look like a personality, and she smiled with a firmness that dared you to disappoint her. Élise had put away her metaphors and lined up her verbs; she plastered the walls with the language of outcomes, and on the board drew the skeleton of her hour so that a person who mistrusted the art might at least appreciate the architecture. At the beginning, the children were loud and then not; Farid refused to remove his shoes in a way that was dignified rather than defensive, and the older girl, whose defiance had become a garment she wore with increasing accuracy, took the boy’s hand in the eyes-closed walk and led him with such fierce delicacy that the committee scarf drooped. Halfway through, while they practiced the scandal of standing still and feeling where their feet were without naming it confession, the woman’s pen stopped moving as if someone had pressed a finger to its mouth. In the little debriefing that followed, the visitor said she had expected “movement” to be more exhausting and less quiet, and Élise, resisting the invitation to witty cruelty, spoke instead about how a body is a city of negotiations and that teaching a child to read their own signals reduces the need to shout later. The next day, an email arrived with the committee’s boiled language approving a pilot extension, and Renaud pinned it to the noticeboard with a flourish as if it were the declaration of a small republic, adding a doodle of a pair of feet in the margin that made the headmaster wince and then pretend not to have seen.

The adults on Tuesday evenings brought with them the smell of their days, which were varied and specific—metal and flour and antiseptic and the ghost of cigarettes that had not, in fact, been smoked. The young woman with protest for hair stood at the edge as if daring the floor to humiliate her personally, and when she was asked simply to walk she burst into a laugh that was too bright to be a laugh. They did not coo at her, because pity is nothing but a mirror held too close; instead, they let her walk badly until her shoulders felt the indecency of carrying so much, and then she allowed, in a tiny surrender that felt like a secret, to be led for three steps by the retired dancer with the knee as if the old woman’s years could be borrowed for a minute like a cardigan against a draft. After class, the man ordered by a doctor to reconnect stayed to wash the cups as if paying reparations to the sink, and told her, without looking up, that his wife had wanted to learn tango and then had instead learned how to die, and he wanted to know if a person who had never held a body properly could still earn the right to try. She answered that permission is not a prize awarded for excellence but a fact one asserts and honors, and that the floor had no memory of their previous failures, and he nodded with that brittle gratitude of people who have built whole afternoons on the hope that someone will not scold them.

Camille arrived one morning with eyes that had decided to be new. She said she had shown the poem to her mother and to her father separately and that in between the two showings she had written another poem that had no jacket in it at all, and that afterwards she had vomited because the body sometimes refuses to be interrupted while it is becoming. There was a small contest at the municipal library with a glass prize that made books look like a religion, and Camille had put her name down with an indifference that betrayed her blood. They discussed nerves as an animal one can feed wisely; they practiced reading the lines aloud at different temperatures, and Élise tried to assume the expression that would make the girl believe in her own mouth. On the day of the reading, the child stood on a low platform with a potted fern that resembled a minor judge and said the line about the jacket in a voice that did not apologize for its audacity, and a woman in the third row who had come primarily to argue with the prizes dabbed her eyes and later pretended the air had been dusty. Camille did not win; she came second to a boy who had written a beautiful lie about a city he had never visited, and on the way out she whispered to Élise that even not winning had felt good in her throat.

They did the practical work of departure without naming it grief. He brought the suitcase to her apartment one evening because its wheels were better on her stairs than his, and because handing a person weight is a way of asking them to bless you without saying the word. He gave her a key that did not belong to him but to a cabinet in the studio where he kept a hoard of things people who are always mending must hoard—electrical tape and bandages and a string that believed itself useful—and told her to take whatever she needed without asking because leaving sometimes requires you to pretend that generosity is a system. On the platform, the train made that show of being coy before opening its mouth to accept him; he kissed her once on each cheek and once in the middle of the air, and then he put his forehead to hers in a gesture that would have made a romance out of them if it had belonged to different people. “I will send you a picture of every leak,” he said, and she said she would send him a picture of her ankle whenever it behaved itself, and then they laughed too loudly because there was water very near the rim of both of them and anyone can see it when the surface trembles. When the train did its trick of leaving while making you believe you were the one who moved, she felt a single foolish tear make an expedition down her nose and onto her lip, and she licked it away with the mindless practicality of a person who has decided to survive.

Alone on the floor, the mirror became less forgiving and more faithful. Without the specific conversation of his hand asking and her back answering, she found that the room had become populated by pasts—errors she had catalogued and resentments she had managed like pot plants. She practiced the first six bars with the minimal civility of a person doing their duty and found herself stalled at the place where the turn had always been a problem, as if problems have their own gravity. There is a comedy in practicing with absence; she could feel the ghost of his palm and almost turn into it, and then she had to teach her muscles not to anticipate charity. The crooked star pressed against her skin under the ordinary shirt like a punctuation mark reminding a sentence of its job; she moved and the star moved and a friendship formed between them that had nothing to do with belief and everything to do with continuity. After an hour, when the body is done pretending it will not cooperate, when the knees have filed their complaints and been heard, she made the turn alone with the precision of a woman placing a cup on a saucer in a room where the child sleeps, and the relief was so unreasonable that she leaned her forehead for a second against the cold mirror and thanked the stupid wall for its attention.

In the small bureaucratic theater of her life, a pleasing farce occurred: the grant came through. It arrived with an email that confessed itself unexpectedly enthusiastic and a PDF that had been saved too many times with different names, and it promised an amount that did not suggest wealth but did suggest persistence might yet be rewarded in this century. She took the news to the librarian because some men can be trusted with joy, and he made her a coffee that did not offend her tongue and said he had always suspected committees were capable of mercy if they were presented with the right adjectives. Renaud threw an arm in the air and declared himself Treasurer of Something, and they laughed because words have always been richer than budgets. She walked home and bought lemons without her breath changing and allowed herself, in so small a decadence it felt almost like a trick, to add a bunch of parsley to the basket because one should teach the refrigerator that color is not an emergency. That evening she wrote to Anne that they ought to waste sugar again, and Anne replied with three ideas and an insult about a critic that promised an afternoon of pleasure.

Because the universe enjoys both symmetry and mischief, she lost the star. It was a mean, quick loss; she had pinned it as always to the inside of her practice shirt and then, after a class in which the boys had discovered the word “suspension” and made it into a physical comedy she had admired against her will, she found her fingers touching only cotton. The panic was not dignified; she searched the bag and the floor and the cruel gap between bench and wall where small objects go to become historical. She retraced her steps through the studio and then to the tram and then to her kitchen, where she looked in the sink because one always looks in the sink, as if the metal might confess to harboring a saint. She went to bed with that hollow between ribs that arrives when a thing you have chosen to believe in goes out without leaving a note, and in the morning she made herself put on her shoes without ceremony and went down to the landlady’s, because courage sometimes looks like doing the day’s stupid things while remembering to say good morning. In the afternoon, while hanging a shirt to dry, she found the star clinging to the inside seam with the ridiculous tenacity of a flea, and she laughed so loudly that the neighbor’s boy peeked through the stair rail to confirm she was alone. She pinned it back with a ferocity that would have frightened a larger jewel, and she scolded it because scolding amulets is foolish and unresisted, and she wore it for the rest of the day even while teaching about prepositions, a fact of which the children were cheerfully ignorant and which improved her mood to an indecent degree.

Renaud, who had fallen in love with competence and then with an opera singer, fell out of love with ease not at all. He arrived one morning in a tie that had not been bullied into cleverness and the eyes of a man who had received a sentence without a verb. Anne had decided that the part of her life in which he had been central must now be remodeled without him, and in the staff room he wavered between eulogy and joke with that dangerous charm people cling to when their grief is new and frightened. She made him tea that tasted of the alphabet and sat with him while he invented versions of himself he might become—ascetic, lothario, beekeeper—and when he had finished she suggested librarian as a temporary vocation and movement assistant as a permanent one. He said the second was absurd and then, to her mild surprise, changed his mind halfway to the bin to throw away the tea bag, because watching children tell the truth with their shoulders had done something to the part of him that usually performed competence until it became a mask. Later that week, he appeared at her lab with a playlist that did not apologize for existing and an offer to count, and she allowed him to, and the numbers he said aloud had a steadiness that made the children taller.

The first snow came mid-lesson like a rumor that turned out to be exact. Someone shrieked the way people do when the air gives them an excuse, and they all went to the window as if it had been written in the curriculum. The flakes were not serious; they were the scouts of an army that might or might not be interested in laying siege to the city, and the courtyard responded by becoming briefly very handsome. She looked at the headmaster through the glass of his office door and he looked back at her and made the small face that principals make when asked for permission to break a rule that is not meant to protect anything important. “Five minutes,” he said, as if the number could contain joy, and she took them all outside and made them walk in a line along the edge of the gritted path with exaggerated slowness while their boots wrote a sentence the snow half-read. The girl with the dangerous shoulders declared that snow itself was a kind of silence that wanted to be listened to, and Farid announced that he had decided to remove his shoes when he felt like it and not a second before, and she told them to breathe because nothing improves an afternoon more cheaply than breathing together in cold air.

At night, when the world goes quiet over debts and dinners, Toulouse came to her telephone, and the phone lit her face the way all lonely cities resemble each other. He called from a room with a curtain that no one had ever meant to buy, and in the square of the screen his smile did its best to be sure of itself. He showed her a blister on a finger that had been bitten by a wire with opinions, and a sandwich so inadequate it had begun to apologize in advance, and an apartment block across the courtyard where a couple argued so patiently it made him want to applaud. Sometimes they spoke with scarecrow lightness, and sometimes they allowed the thread to carry quiet over hundreds of kilometers without insisting on filling it, and then she would walk with the phone pressed to her ear to her window, and he would listen to the sound of her radiator’s arrogance as if it were proof that he would be permitted to come back. The first Sunday, he sent a photograph of a leak that had given up its location with theatrical reluctance, annotated with arrows and a drawing of a fish, and she replied with a video of her ankle behaving itself in a circle and the star lying on her palm like an accomplice. They hung up when the connection began to fragment his vowels into birds, and afterwards she stood with her face close to the cold of the window until the city gave her back to herself.

There were days when the bell at her sternum rang so low she worried she’d mistaken it for a dull ache; there were days it chimed at a pitch that made the glass on the shelf hum along, which is a ridiculous thing to say out loud and entirely true. The cultural center’s posters appeared in the world and she saw her own name next to words like “community” and “embodiment,” and she felt both flattered and hunted. An old man came to class wearing a suit because the idea of exercise offended him and left wearing a sweater because the idea had apologized and then been permitted to enter; a woman confessed to having danced at weddings only behind pillars and was witnessed out in the open by strangers who did not make a joke of her. After one such class, the protest-haired girl approached and asked what to do when she looked at herself and hated the arrangement of things in an almost professional way, and Élise told her to make the mirror work for its wage and to stand so close to the glass it could not find all of her at once, and that in the end a person must decide who is the customer in that transaction. They laughed, and the girl tried, and afterward she wrote a message that said only “I am still here,” which was either nothing or the thing itself.

A small embarrassment went round the staff room when a parent complained that the laboratory had resulted in their child’s unusual determination to walk too slowly in supermarkets, as if the aisles had become an audience. The headmaster forwarded the message with a subject line scaffolding—concern, which made her fond of him because everyone deserves a little theater in their caution. She wrote back to the parent with all the charm she could afford that there were worse rebellions than making the world wait for a person who was learning to take up their own time, and the parent replied, unexpectedly, that the boy had started making tea and that perhaps the connection was not coincidental. Renaud made a poster for the lab that featured a drawing of feet reading a book, and he hung it under a crooked notice about detentions that had remained crooked for such a long time that the crookedness had become part of the aesthetic. She made him straighten it because there are rules one must obey even when one is busy inventing others.

On a Thursday near the end of term, when everyone is too tired to pretend they like each other and therefore can be liked, she found herself in the park under the chestnuts just before evening, because she had taken the long way home in order to prove she did not belong entirely to the grids of the day. She watched a boy teach his father how to throw a paper plane with the correct sticking-out tongue, and a woman argue with a dog about mud as if the animal understood the politesse of flooring, and she thought about the year that had been too much of everything and somehow also parsimonious with miracles. The star lay obediently against her sternum; the gladiators had collected a thin layer of dust in the staff room, which made them look older and therefore more credible; the lab had a budget that would not survive a hungry committee but might survive careful stapling; Camille had a new poem that refused to behave and might become a life. When she got home, she found a package under the door from Anne containing two jars of jam labeled with handwriting that had a bias toward melodrama—one read Winter Citrus for Courage, the other read Bitter Peel for Truth—and a note that said, simply, eat the second when you are infuriated by the first.

That night the dream arrived again, with the hall and the floor that tolerated only her feet, but this time the chairs were occupied by her living—the librarian, Renaud, the girl with the protest hair, the old woman with the fuchsia backpack, the headmaster pretending not to be moved, Jules with a child on each knee, Anne with her pins like medals, and, in a deep shadow where one is not expected to identify one’s devils, her mother, who looked neither approving nor discouraging but attentive in a way that felt more like friendship than review. She woke in the place just before her clock had been asked to perform its small act of heroism, and lay with the knowledge that sleep had not betrayed her by telling her unuseful truths. The radiator argued with itself without taking sides; the city outside made its quiet inventory of lamps and cats and buses; her body rehearsed the mild ache of being a person who has used it. She put her hand to her sternum, felt the bell’s long note, and considered, briefly and then persistently, that perhaps the door she had spent her life tapping at had not been opened by someone else but by her knuckles having knocked a groove into it at last. She got up because mornings hold their own kind of ceremony, and because tea does not make itself, and because there would be children to teach to walk slower and a man to call in another city where the curtains still had not chosen to be beautiful, and because cost and joy had their account to reconcile in the ledger she carried around like a private book of hours.Chapter 10

February had a way of arranging itself like a badly folded map, all creases in the wrong directions, and she walked through it with the tolerant irritation one reserves for furniture that cannot be moved. The river took on the posture of a patient in a waiting room, determined to appear untroubled, and the air acquired that taste of wet keys that winter dispenses when it wants to remind you who is in charge of locks. She tied her scarf with the firmness of someone closing an argument and counted, without admitting it to herself, the mornings until the first daffodil would be reckless on the quai. The bell at her sternum continued its plain work, so steady now that she could measure the day by its hum, and she had the absurd thought that if she put her ear against the window she would hear the city ring back.

The laboratory had become a country with customs and, inevitably, smuggling. A boy tried to bring swagger across the border and had it confiscated at the door but, uninspected, kindness slipped through in his pockets; a girl attempted, unsuccessfully, to hide her need for applause inside disdain, and another girl spotted it and held it up to the light like a jewel in a pawnshop. On the third Monday, they attempted the technique of leaving space between steps not as negligence but as offer, and it turned into a minor theology when Farid, who had finally taken off his shoes in a silent ceremony that involved knotting his laces with dignity and placing them side by side as if they were friends, declared that the empty parts were the best because you could sit down inside them without anyone seeing. She wanted to clap and did not, because you must not reward children for discovering something they cannot yet protect; instead she taught them the practical trick of counting silence as if it were a note. The committee lady returned, scarf subdued, and stayed longer than her schedule would have wished, her pen making more pauses than words.

Camille arrived one morning with a bruise under her sleeve that was not a bruise but a blue ink stain from a pen that had exploded while she was writing in bed, and her face had that satisfied exhaustion of someone who has argued with themselves and not lost. She produced a poem that refused to end where she had meant it to, and they laughed over its insubordination and agreed to let it have the last word for a while. When the municipal library published the list of finalists for the glass prize, Camille’s name had mischief in its vowels, and her mother sent a message to say she would attend with a stoic coat and a resolve not to say anything injurious about metaphors in public. The reading itself was lit with that inexpensive brightness that makes everyone look briefly like someone else, and Camille’s voice had found the height at which it could speak without arousing the suspicion of the ceiling. She did not win, which was correct because winning would have made her insufferable for a fortnight, but afterward a woman with hair like punctuation came and told her she had done something honest to an afternoon, and the girl measured the sentence as if it were fabric she could use later.

Toulouse tattooed itself into Rafaël’s messages with the cheap ink of temporary lodgings—curtains the color of disappointment, a kettle that took offense if filled past its line, a neighbor who sang softly and could not carry a tune even through a thin wall. He called from streets with names that had opinions, and once from a bar where a man told a joke about electricity that could not be translated without being killed. The job, of course, tried to grow; it insisted on an extra two weeks in a tone of voice the foreman called unavoidable and that reminded her of the phrase we have no choice used politely as an instrument. He rehearsed leaving again without complaint, and she practiced the art of not making a friend into a martyr by praising his absence too eloquently. When he sent a photograph of his wrist healed to the color of a lesson learned, she replied with a photograph of the crooked star resting on her sternum like a punctuation mark that had decided not to move, and he texted back a small constellation made of dots and dashes and a fish because there are love languages that are not languages and ought not to be named.

There are, inside schools, small storms that never make the news, and one gathered in the staff room over paper cups and the smell of coffee that was trying to forgive itself. A parent wrote to the committee to say the laboratory had emboldened her child to sway in the aisle of the supermarket while choosing yogurt, which she found extravagant and, perhaps, communist. The headmaster, who had learned from years of bats in attics that fear can climb through any crack, forwarded the message with a sigh that had practiced being dignified. Élise drafted a reply that used words like proprioception and attention economy and then deleted it because both words would turn into weapons when repeated in kitchens and on buses, and instead wrote that the boy would grow up into a person who could stand in a line without resenting the stranger in front of him, and that the country would be better for it. The parent, unexpectedly, responded that he had, in fact, helped an old woman reach the top shelf where the jam lived, and that perhaps this was what they were paying for after all, and she printed the missile and pinned it under the gladiators because not all victories have trumpets and most deserve shelves.

A small celebration in late afternoon was arranged by accident when the librarian produced a pan of something that had once been cake and now had ambitions to be history, and Renaud arrived with a bottle of apple juice that he insisted was festive and which tasted like an orchard with anxieties. They ate and called it a committee meeting and laughed the way people laugh when they have believed a thing and been rewarded enough to make superstition reasonable. Renaud wore a new tie with tiny bicycles that made him look as if he had joined an eccentric government, and he had begun to help with the lab in a way that made her proud of him, not because he was competent, which he had always been in front of adults, but because his counting had adopted mercy as one of its digits. Anne sent a message to both of them saying she had been offered a role that required her to sing in a dress the color of suspicion and that she had accepted not for the dress but for a scene in which she would be permitted to make a gentleman cry, and he wrote back with seven hearts and a lemon, and after a pause she sent him a photograph of the stage lights like coins thrown in a fountain, and the three of them sat in different rooms being properly fond of one another without requiring proof.

In the city, weather found an excuse to flex, and a snow decided to matter. It arrived not with scouts but with infantry, fat flakes marching with pomp into the peripheries of plans, and by dark the streets had that purposeful hush that suggests conspiracies of good behavior. The electricity considered its options and chose, for a few hours, to be absent in several neighborhoods, and the corridor in her building filled with candlelight that made everyone look like apparitions summoned by the love lives of furniture. The elevator, which had never been reliable enough to become loved, surrendered with a sigh and trapped a young man on his way to a second date, and the neighbor’s boy, solemn with role, went and fetched Madame Hanriot, who had a key that was not universal but had learned to pretend. People spoke in the tone reserved for recipes and disasters; someone discovered that the stairwell had excellent acoustics, and someone else, without permission but with tact, began to hum a tune that aspired to be a lullaby. The old woman with the fuchsia backpack arrived with a thermos of something medicinal and hopeful, and before anyone could stop them Élise and the boy were showing an impromptu line of neighbors how to walk silently down a flight in the dark without fearing their ankles. There, in the stairwell that had spent years being merely a place to not linger, a small dance formed—a soft exchange of weight and trust, a mother entrusting a toddler to the banister and being rewarded, a teenager allowed to lead a grandfather without irony. When the lights returned with their blare and apology, no one cheered; they simply looked at each other with that embarrassed gratitude that follows unjustified kindness, and the young man went to his second date smelling faintly of wax and pancakes and having learned that an elevator can be an origin story.

A letter with an eagle printed in blue arrived from the municipal cultural office with the good arrogance of paper that has been handled by many desks, and it informed her, with blameless formulations, that the grant money would be released in two parts, one now and one after counts had been counted, and that she was to spend some of it on something the letter called documentation. She bought a notebook the size of a sandwich and a camera that had been loved by someone else and approved of recording people who had not asked for it. She wrote down the names of songs they did not use and the moments children laughed because someone had tripped on a silence, and she took pictures of shoes lined up like sheep at the edge of a hill and of the corner of the studio where dust performed its quiet occupation. She kept the receipts because the future loves paper, and one afternoon she allowed herself to buy a secondhand coat lined with a fake fur that felt like the kindness of strangers, and she wore it to the market like a person who has admitted winter is not a rumor and has decided to look it in the eye.

Toulouse sent him home for a weekend the way long distances sometimes grant parole for good behavior. He arrived with the damp of a different city on his cuffs and a sleep in his eyes that belonged to trains, and in the studio he stood for a minute as if asking the room to remember him. They did not attempt the reckless parts immediately; they walked like people sanely grateful for two legs, then counted without counting because their mouths had missed the numbers, and then marked the turn with that near-religious caution dancers employ around pivots, as if the earth’s patience were not infinite after all. He smelled of metal and sandwiches; she smelled of chalk and ink; they smelled, together, of a place that can be returned to without apology. After an hour, as if obeying a calendar neither had consulted, they put the music on and did the thing their bodies have been instructed to do by months of instruction, and it was messy like happiness and accurate like habit, and when it ended he was laughing and she was not, and then she laughed because the alternative would have involved something too big for an ordinary afternoon.

He had a new habit of putting his hand on the rail as they walked down the studio steps, as if his wrists were still tender and gravity had become opinionated. She noticed and did not mention it; he noticed that she noticed and did not tell his hands to behave. Over a beer that pretended to be bread, they spoke about the job and the offer of its extension and how a city is always willing to keep you if you prove yourself willing to be lonely there. He asked about the lab and she told him a story about Farid and socks that was not interesting on paper and made him put his head down on his arm and breathe as if rescued. They did not discuss what they were to one another because the table was too small for that kind of furniture and because, more importantly, they had not been able to dance for weeks and no sentence could be trusted not to sabotage that fact. When she walked him back to the train, he carried the suitcase between them with one hand and let the other brush her shoulder high, a touch that had no right to be as serious as it felt. He promised to send a photograph of the first plane trees when they grew foolish at the canal, and she promised to send the sound of her radiator when it began again its spring cluck, and neither commented on how slowly a platform releases a body once a train has left.

The showcase videos did their rounds and landed, like resigned pigeons, on a page that the students found with the ruthless efficiency of youth. One by one they presented her with her own face between classes like a bouquet with thorns; she accepted it each time with the grin of a woman who has been caught out performing devotion in the open, and fought the urge to apologize for earnestness in a thin sweater. A parent stopped her in the street to say her daughter had begun to walk at home with a small dignity that did not match the family’s furniture, and Élise nodded and pretended to have this effect all the time. Another parent, this one the kind who makes enemies of ideas before meeting them, sent a message demanding to know exactly how stillness could possibly prepare a child for life, and she responded gently that standing with accuracy is the foundation of almost every useful rebellion she had ever seen, and then she closed her phone and went to the studio and practiced not thinking about proof.

Jules sent a photograph of the girls attacking a snowman with political grievances, and beneath it a sentence saying that he had been offered more hours at the bureau in exchange for his weekends, which he did not want to give up because those were the days when he believed in parks and small museums and the act of showing little people how to make soup. She wrote back that money is a liar and that there are values other than rent, then appended, because she is not an idiot, a recipe for a soup that uses potatoes and pride in equal measure and costs less than missing a Saturday. He called that night and they argued the way people argue when money has placed a hand on their shoulders without asking, efficient and unkind and then repentant, and they ended with the sibling truce of insulting each other’s competence and the promise of tea. After, she stood in the kitchen with the coat folded over a chair like a patient animal and stared at the lemons, which had taken on for the moment the look of witnesses.

At the end of the month, the cultural center staged an end-of-winter gathering of all the strange classes it housed—pottery and pies and Portuguese, a choir with more ambition than pitch, a knitting circle whose members could have intimidated armies. They took to the hall with their shy ferocities, and in a pause between a gavotte and a speech that bullied the word community into doing too much work, she led her adults in a short walk across a floor that had been polished by earnestness. The protest-haired girl did not protest; the retired dancer’s knee performed with the weightless vanity of an old star; the man who had been ordered to reconnect held out his hands with the self-forgiveness of someone at last prepared to drop a weapon. A boy from the pottery class clapped with alarming sincerity, and someone yelled bravo with enough accent to make it a gift. Afterwards, in the crush of people behaving responsibly toward pastries, a woman with a face like a solved mystery told Élise she had been watching from the door because she was not ready to belong to anything yet, and that watching had made her ribcage less a cage and more an instrument. The phrase was a cliché and a miracle. They stood there for a minute breathing like new friends until a tray demanded attention, and then they allowed real life back in.

March opened the window by half an inch and dared everyone to be optimistic. The rain changed its handwriting; the butcher’s fennel gave up medicine and returned to mischief; the river decided to resume gossip. She woke one morning to a light that had made its mind up about the future and a message from Toulouse that contained only a photograph of a plane tree doing its obscene green, and she laughed aloud because vulgarity can be moral in moderate quantities. The headmaster sent word that the committee had granted the lab enough money to last through spring provided she supplied testimonials, and she spent an evening calling parents to ask for sentences that did not sound like they had been composed beneath a threatening lamp. The answers came like gifts left on doorsteps—my son is gentler with doors now, my daughter corrected her grandfather’s posture in the queue for croissants, my child breathes as if her own body is a place and not an enemy—and she wrote them down without polishing, because the truth does not need cologne.

On a Thursday that smelled of new mud, the old woman with the fuchsia backpack invited her to a dance she described as respectable only from a distance. It was one of those Sunday afternoons in a gymnasium hired by people who believe they can charm a linoleum floor, and they could, mostly, because they had learned to bring their own light under their cardigans. The music was both too loud and not loud enough; the men shook hands with their nerves while the women held their chins with the practiced ease of queens of small countries; there was a raffle featuring a ham. Élise danced with three strangers who were all portions of a man she might once have thought she wanted—gentle, clumsy, certain—and with one woman who offered to lead and did so with an elegance that made her bones applaud. Between numbers she stood with the old woman and watched the couples go by and learned a taxonomy of joy that had nothing to do with youth and everything to do with permission. On their way out, they crossed the car park between puddles that had memorized the boots of the city, and the old woman said that of all the immodest things human beings insist on doing, learning with the body in public is the one she respects most, and Élise tucked the sentence under her tongue for later like a sugar.

The studio, when not borrowed by revolving classes, belonged to her in a way that felt almost liturgical. Alone now in the afternoons that could be spared, she arranged the chairs along the wall as if seating donors at a banquet, set the metronome to a compromise, and walked the phrase that had eluded her for a year with the tender patience of someone coaxing a cat from beneath a bed. Without him there to correct and be corrected, she discovered corners she had not known the room possessed. There is a laurel one can rest under that grows even in the absence of victory—you have come back, it says, which is the point—and she accepted its shade without writing a speech about it. Once, in the middle of a turn that had always required an apology, she felt the star press insistently against her sternum right at the moment when her foot would choose, and the choice was sudden and obvious and exactly correct; she laughed alone in the room and bowed to nobody for having decided to remain alive and to perform that aliveness in an unfashionable, inefficient, undignified way.

In the late afternoons after the lab, the courtyard filled with the kind of arguments that restore faith in the populace—four children disagreeing about the ethics of cutting in line for the water fountain with the vocabulary of a parliament and the volume control of seagulls. She walked home slower because there is a kind of gratitude that demands dawdling, and on the bridge she encountered the headmaster practicing his own dawdle, hands behind his back in the posture of a man examining policy through the lens of birds. He thanked her, with more economy than usual, for the sentences parents had sent, and confessed, as if to a crime, that he had tried standing still for one minute the night before between the refrigerator and the sink and had found the activity shocking. She told him he could start a movement, and he said he had started a movement when he chose a life that contained detention slips, and they laughed with the rare ease of colleagues who have, for an afternoon, misplaced their weariness.

Rafaël returned for good on a day that pretended not to be triumphant. He came with two bags and an extra line near his left eye that had not been there before and made him look more like himself. The city received him with a shrug that functioned as welcome; the studio, with its indifferent floor and its faithful mirrors, offered him no discount, which was also a form of love. They practiced the piece and then did not, abandoning it for the foolishness of a rhythm neither would ever perform in public because it required too much forgetting. In the pause between tracks, he said there was an offer to go back in summer to a site that promised to pay and to break and asked, in a tone that the bell in her recognized as fear disguised as courtesy, whether she thought he should. She answered with the cruelty of honesty that she did not intend to be cruel, telling him she wanted him here and that she would applaud him if he left, and that for the first time in her entire life she was able to imagine asking someone to stay without confusing the request with a threat, and he listened with the stillness of a man standing under weather and deciding whether it is rain or baptism. They did not solve it; they danced again instead, which is not a solution but is a system, and it kept them from saying the ugly sentences later disguised as noble.

On the way home that night, the tram made an unplanned halt between stations where the city is all weeds and confessions, and for five minutes a car of strangers did the revolution of accepting each other. A woman removed a paper star from her coat and handed it to a child who had been patient; a man looked up from his phone with the expression of someone realizing his own face is not so bad; two teenagers performed the small tender cruelty of pretending not to be in love. She stood holding the pole and felt the weird mercy of a pause you did not request and could not lengthen, and when the tram started again the city returned to its ungenerous grace and she tagged along as if invited.

At home, the crooked star lay cooling against her sternum and the gladiators kept their watch over the plant that refused to be a tree but insisted upon hope. She set the new notebook on the table with its pages that looked like certainty and wrote down nothing for a while, letting the pen rest its weight on the paper the way a foot finds the floor and waits for it to respond. The bell at her sternum sounded low and friendly, an old clock that would, she suspected, continue to ring even if the city went briefly mad with spring and then with disappointment. She opened the window, listened to the water dumpsters gossip in the alley, and put on a record that made the kitchen behave like a considerate partner. It was not a victory night or a debt night; it was simply a continuing, and she stood in it the way one stands in a shower that takes a moment to decide who it belongs to and then, benevolently, concedes.
